column8: Wilpattu National Park, off the beaten path, not to be missed!
column11: Amazing park with very diverse habitats, and not crowded. We were expertly guided by Raj Fernando, of Leopard Trails. He has deep and detailed knowledge of the wildlife. We like to learn as much as we can about the nature and wildlife around, and Raj thoroughly impressed us with his knowledge. He is also a most gracious person, very well organised and service oriented, nothing was too much for him and our expert driver Dinesh. We saw leopard, elephant, bear, wild boar, crocs, and many many bird species. Just a glance at a distant spot was enough for Raj to identify a bird and tell us all about the species. Thanks to Raj and Dinesh, visiting Wilpattu national park was an unforgettable experience, a treasure not to be missed.

Wilpattu National Park is Sri Lanka‚Äôs largest and most tranquil wildlife sanctuary, famous for its unique natural lakes called ‚Äúvillus.‚Äù It offers excellent chances to spot leopards, sloth bears, elephants, deer, and rich birdlife. With dense forests and peaceful landscapes, it provides a serene, less-crowded safari experience.

column8: Not as crowded as Yala: a real alternative for leopard lovers
column11: A jeep safari in the Wilpattu - I've been there 5 times - requires a lot of patience, because you jerk through dense forest for an hour before you get into the open countryside.....unfortunately I've never seen a leopard, but fortunately our customers have. There are otherwise Axish deer to see, sometimes a muntjac, crocodiles, isolated elephants, wild boars. Beautiful also the Kumbuk trees at the watercourses.

I had already done the safari in Yala but I really liked this too. Very large area where spotting animals can be more difficult but it is worth immersing yourself in the nature and sounds that the park offers.

DONT DO THE ALL DAY SAFARI! Having done 2 safari tours in Sri Lanka thus far we travelled to Wilpatu for a short stay near the Wilpatu national park. The town is dead with really nothing to do outside the hotel. We had booked a full day safari which in my opinion was a big mistake. Take my advice & opt for 2 to 4 hours experience if you choose this activity. The terrain is expectedly extremely harsh so after bouncing up & down for 10 hours my body is now rather suffering. Don‚Äôt get me wrong our guide was brilliant & if the animals were there to spot he spotted them. The trouble is, & it may have just been a bad day that there weren‚Äôt that many to spot so sometimes sightings were an hour apart. Additionally the guides/drivers for some reason have to stop & chat everytime they pass each other. I get they want to share if they‚Äôve spottted anything so others can enjoy but with over 70 vehicles buzzing round this space & stopping every time they pass each other even if they‚Äôve passed each other 10 times previously it starts to become a little infuriating. This does however give you the opportunity to observe your fellow safari goers faces in the other vehicles which pretty much all had expressions of extreme boredom. There is impressive wildlife in the park so like I said if you choose to visit just do a short tour.

column8: If you're unlucky you hardly see animals.
column11: The basic idea of a safari is to see animals and in this sense we were unlucky: 1 elephant, 1 and a half crocodile, some buffalo, several fawn herds and most notably, two trees full of storks with their chicks. No bear, no leopard.  Pretty poor for a 4h safari that cost us over 60‚Ç¨ per person.

column8: It's not comparable to safaris in Africa.
column11: A disappointing experience. Leopards and bears are for sale, but neither was seen. There are about 6 leopards in the area where the Jeep is going. After breakfast, we got word of a leopard and headed there, but it was already a long traffic jam and the leopard was gone while we waited. Except for leopards and bears, most of them can be found just driving around normally, so I think it would be good if they specialized in leopard hunting. Don't seem happy with peacocks. Beautiful little birds to check out. As usual, monkeys are found in various ruins. I got the impression that there was not as much exchange of information between drivers as in Africa. The road is also very bumpy and very tiring.

We really enjoyed our safari in Wilpattu, the lakes are just beautiful - the forests are quite close to the roads, so can sometimes be tricky to see wildlife, but more rewarding when you do. We had a close encounter with a sloth bear and a fleeting view of a leopard. Recommend spending a full day so you can spend quality time in the more distant locations - it‚Äôs a huge park.

We had booked a full day safari that starts at 06:00. It is mass tourism where the rangers / drivers push before six to get the entrance tickets for their guests. Then 45 minutes in motorcade on a sandy path through the forest to the location where almost every safari jeep stops for a breakfast break. Along the way we did stop a few times to spot a few bird species, a crocodile and a large number of deer. After breakfast we continued our way and apart from a lonely elephant in a lake we did not see any new animals. This while the park is known for its population of leopards and lip bears. Due to the monotony of the surroundings (forest, sandy path, lake) and the lack of visibility of animals, boredom struck at some point and we returned home around noon. Entrance fee is USD 29.50 incl. VAT for an adult and USD 17.70 incl. VAT for a child up to 12 years old. In addition, depending on the size of the party and the length of the Safari (morning, afternoon, full day), you pay an amount for the car + driver. We have no experience with other parks in Sri Lanka but we would not recommend Wilpattu.

We visited Wilpattu on 1st February for a full day tour, it was definitely the highlight of our trip.  We has an amazing guide, Chumi, who was incredible at spotting the birds and animals.  We kept a list (and took over 200 photos), with his help, and although we didn't record absolutely everything, we did note over 35 different bird species (a special interest of ours) and around 15 different mammals and reptiles, including elephants, crocodiles, leopards and Sri Lanka bear.  The leopard was very relaxed and we got lots of great photos, and were lucky enough to see it hunting, catching a mouse deer right by the side of the track.  Amazing.  Most visiting tourists push for seeing the ‚Äúbig 5‚Äù - elephants, water buffalo, crocodiles, leopards and bear (and we did see all of these) but Wilpattu is a fantastic park with lots more to offer and it's much better not to press your guide into rushing around.  Take some time to really look and give your guide a chance to point out wildlife, it is a wonderful National Park and an unforgettable experience. Highly recommended.

Over several trips we had the good fortune to see many animals, leopards with youngsters, bears and even a jackal.  We also went with a bird expert who opened our eyes to the extensive bird life in the park.  My key memory is the landscape around the various lakes, especially beautiful, especially combined with dramatic and varied wildlife.  The park is a dream but the state of roads is a disgrace.  Only suitable for fit and able passengers - not so good for granny or mums-to-be. .

Travelling around Sri Lanka we were very impressed by the quality of the roads, including those to quite small rural communities. The main route for visitors within Wilpattu is a disgrace, which we are told cannot just  be blamed just on weather. This is one of the locations promoted for tourists, and the constantly bumpy journey eroded the pleasure of driving through forest and more open landscapes. Yes it is good to see animals and birds, but by sharp contrast with the tracks in public national parts of southern Africa, this is a shocker. The driver/guides in their jeeps do their very best for visitors, but in response to observations about the road they must face, they say that the relevant authority needs to be pursued. The park makes significant money from tourism and tourists deserve to have some of it returned to them in the form of an acceptable journey.

This is the first national park we visited in Sri Lanka and you have to be lucky to see animals in the wild, but we found the outcome in this park very meagre in terms of seeing animals after a trip of almost 4 hours it was just some peacocks, dragons, buffalo and a few birds.

Wilpattu was an incredible experience‚Äîso serene and untouched. The park is less crowded than others, which made the safari feel more intimate and authentic. We spotted elephants, deer, and even a leopard from a distance! The landscape is beautiful with its natural lakes (called villus) and thick forest. Our guide was friendly and knew a lot about the park‚Äôs unique ecosystem. If you love nature and want a calm, immersive safari, Wilpattu is the place to go.

We visited both Yala and Wilpattu and Wilpattu was far superior in terms of amount of animals we saw, behaviour of jeeps/drivers and the natural beauty of the park.  Yala seemed quite barren.  We saw a leopard and suddenly you are surrounded by jeeps but it wasn't as aggressive as Yala which bordered on dangerous. We enjoyed our full day safari here.  Some of the roads are well worn and were full of clay coloured water and you really wonder if you are going to get stuck, but that was part of the fun.  We didn't see a sloth bear unfortunately.  We watched a couple of elephants pulling grasses from the bottom of a lake, shake them around then eat them.  It was relaxing.  Loads of birds but I found them very hard to photograph.  Loads of monkeys at the rest stop.  If I could only visit one park it would 100% be Wilpattu.

The park is very beautiful, but it felt very double how the safari went. You drive in jeeps in (luckily) a small area of the park. The drivers would like to show you all the animals and as a result about 50 to 100 jeeps are racing around the park. The drivers warn each other if they have spotted an animal and then all tear to the same spot. As a result, the beast is long gone. I understand it's their source of income, but unfortunately it didn't match my gut...

Wilpatu is definitely a very nice park. I must say I found it quite busy with cars. If an animal has been seen, it's a race to be in front. Otherwise beautiful, lots of water and lots of animals seen. Unfortunately not the elephant or the leopard. Entrance is on the pricey side

Wilpattu is a beautiful park and there is plenty to see. We were satisfied with everything we saw including 1 leopard. What was striking at the entrance to the park is that of the approximately 40 4x4 jeeps that were parked, approximately 90% only had 2 passengers, the average number of passengers per Jeep is now approximately 2.2. That is strange because we and some other visitors had indicated in advance that we wanted to share a jeep to save costs. The park management chooses to send as many jeeps into the park as possible because they earn more this way. This does not benefit the welfare of the animals, cars disrupt the peace of the animals. If a rare animal is spotted, 10-15 jeeps will be around it within a few minutes. The park management should aim for an average of 4 passengera per jeep, which will halve the traffic in the park. What else stands out is: At the lunch spot it is mainly the drivers who throw waste on the ground. You also see many drivers feeding animals so that their clients can take close ups of the animals. There is no enforcement of applicable rules, such as the ban on feeding and leaving waste. Our driver spoke very poor English. He knew the names of all the animals but there was no point in asking him a question, he never understood it, his English was too bad. Most drivers work long hours (5:30 AM - 6:30 PM) and our driver used a lot of betel nuts to stay awake. In the afternoon, other Jeeps regularly stopped next to us and our driver handed out beetle nuts with the other drivers. Use of betel nuts by drivers is dangerous because it masks symptoms of fatigue and is addictive. The park management would be better off using 4 passengers per jeep and 2 drivers per jeep so that they can take turns resting. Many drivers don't go far into the park and stay a short distance from the lunch spot. It would be better to drive deeper into the park, most of the animals (especially elephants) are in the north-west side of the park, at least an hour's drive from the lunch spot. To guarantee the continued existence of the park, the park management should allow a maximum number of vehicles per day and encourage the distribution of vehicles in the park. Monitor behaviour and enforcement of park regulations and ban on stimulants by staff.

Wilpattu National Park is one of Sri Lanka's oldest and largest wildlife parks, perfect for nature lovers, wildlife enthusiasts, and bird watchers. Spanning over 1,300 square kilometers, it is known as the "Land of Lakes" due to its many natural lakes, which attract a variety of animals. The park is famous for its leopards, making it a top destination to see these majestic big cats. Visitors can also spot elephants, sloth bears, deer, water buffalo, and many other animals. For bird watchers, Wilpattu is home to over 200 bird species, including colorful peacocks, eagles, and water birds like storks and cormorants. What makes Wilpattu special is its peaceful and uncrowded atmosphere. The vast park offers a mix of thick forests, open grasslands, and wetlands, making every safari feel unique and exciting. It‚Äôs an ideal place to experience the beauty of Sri Lanka‚Äôs wilderness without the hustle and bustle. Wilpattu also holds historical significance, as it‚Äôs believed to be where Prince Vijaya, the founder of the Sinhalese race, first landed in Sri Lanka. Whether you're into wildlife, birdwatching, or just seeking a peaceful escape into nature, Wilpattu promises an unforgettable experience with its untouched beauty and rich biodiversity.

Don't expect it to be less crowded than Yala. 85% of the time we drove along dirt roads with a 5 to 10 meter strip on both sides cleared with a trimmer. Beyond that it's thick bush and you can't see anything. Once in a while you get to a clearing. We saw lots of deer, peakock and birds. Than spotted a bear with a cub. At that moment about 40 4x4s pushed in and infront of each other to get the best view while blocking the view of others. The bears didn't seem to mind but took off after a few minutes. Than the race began! Vehicles speeding around the clearing to catch another view on the other side, overtaking and litterally bumping into each other. We had a terrible car (most seemed better and more comfortable) and the roads were EXTREMLY bumpy. I did safaris before and own a 4x4 myself but this was aweful. The bad condition of the roads might have been due to the continuous heavy rains over the last weeks (although end of January). Even our kids (who did not complain when we travelled in two tuktuks with five people and 6 large suitcases for half an hour on bumpy roads in Ella - yes, it's possible) were glad when we saw the entrance gate again. Quote: "I think it's over. Thank god!"

This park is famous for leopard sightings but there are no guarantees - we did a full day (10hr) safari and saw many animals including a bear up close but no leopards. Our time there was just after some rains and it appeared that the animals really come out on dry days. Still, it was an enjoyable day - there were probably another 8-10 jeeps in the park, all hunting leopard sightings but it seemed only one jeep had managed a sighting. Reasonable facilities inside the park at the lunch venue.

We had a full day safari in a private jeep in Wilpattu and what a great day it was.  So many animals and birds - 7 Leopard sightings including a large male and a female with cubs.  A disorganised start to the day - it took our driver/guide a while to get through the entrance procedures (reminded us of India) and would have preferred to be in for first light. A large park, we were often on our own with no other jeeps around, although at the Leopard sightings it was an absolute traffic jam (apart from the big male when we were on our own). The drivers/guides were in our view getting too close to the animals and pursuing them for longer than we felt comfortable with.  This is a training issue for the NP, but still a 5 star experience.

Compared to many national parks in Sri Lanka, this park offers a truly immersive experience. The large forest area can be explored using trails that showcase the park‚Äôs rich biodiversity. Various safari tours are available, including full-day and half-day options, and the drivers provide excellent service. One of the main attractions is the Sri Lankan leopard, which you might spot if you‚Äôre lucky. To increase your chances, remember to enter the park early, around 6 AM. When visiting, make sure to bring enough water and snacks, as you will travel a considerable distance from the entrance. The climate is hot and dusty, so be prepared for that. In addition to leopards, you can also see other animals like sloth bears, deer, various bird species, elephants, and wild boars.

Modulate expectations because not many animals (heads of 2 crocodiles, several groups of herbivores, varan, leopard shadow, and an elephant resident in a lake), many boats, not too much landscape variety. Non-intercom guides, and too many 4x4s. Too big. No more than 6.

We visited Wilpattu National Park last Sunday, and it was an incredible experience! We were lucky enough to spot a leopard, a sloth bear, and several elephants, which made the adventure truly unforgettable. The park's natural beauty is breathtaking, and it was a thrill to see these animals in their natural habitat. After the safari, we also visited a nearby beach. The view from the uphill was simply stunning‚Äîa perfect way to end the day. Our driver was very friendly and knowledgeable, adding to the overall positive experience. The trip was well worth it, and I highly recommend this adventure to anyone looking for a memorable experience in nature

Wilpattu National Park is a true gem of Sri Lanka‚Äôs natural landscape, and guiding visitors through this pristine wilderness is always a remarkable experience. As a tour guide, I‚Äôm continually impressed by the park‚Äôs untouched beauty and its reputation as one of the best locations for leopard sightings in the country. The park‚Äôs diverse ecosystems, from dense forests to open plains and serene water bodies, create a dynamic environment that supports a rich array of wildlife. One of the most exciting aspects of guiding in Wilpattu is the thrill of tracking and spotting the elusive leopard, a highlight for many visitors. The park‚Äôs relatively low visitor numbers mean that encounters with these magnificent big cats are often more intimate and rewarding. The park‚Äôs sheer size and varied landscapes offer an ever-changing safari experience. From navigating through the jungle to exploring the open plains, each game drive provides unique opportunities for wildlife observation. The sight of elephants roaming freely, the occasional glimpse of a sloth bear, and the vibrant birdlife add to the park‚Äôs allure. One of the things I love most about Wilpattu is its sense of solitude and immersion in nature. The park‚Äôs tranquil setting allows visitors to connect deeply with the natural world, away from the more crowded tourist spots. Sharing this serene and untamed beauty with travelers is incredibly fulfilling. For anyone looking to experience Sri Lanka‚Äôs wild side, Wilpattu National Park is an absolute must-visit. Its rich wildlife, stunning landscapes, and the thrill of leopard spotting make it a standout destination. Join us on a safari and discover the enchanting wilderness of Wilpattu for yourself.

Park devoid of animals and extremely expensive a lost morning. Really inadmissible we just saw buffaloes, dain, birds. A tourist catch considering the jeep numbers. Elephants are hidden as well as leopards and crocodiles may have gone on holiday. Extremely disappointed for a first safari.

Very disappointed! We were led to believe that this park was home to many animals and in reality I will describe this activity (because it is not a safari but a jeep ride in a forest) as a walk to see birds with buffaloes, peacocks and deer as bonuses. We walk in a forest on a not very interesting track; original trees with "artistic" trunks but really nothing folichon. And I'm not jaded because this is my first time doing this activity. We were a family of 10 who visited Wilpattu National Park in May 2023. We had a great trip with good weather. Unfortunately we didn't get to see many animals, but some elephants and deer were observed from a distance. The trip can be recommended to everyone of all ages.
Because of Wilpattu, it is a good and beautiful place where you can see a lot of animals. Sri  lanka ....................

There are dozens of jeeps in this park, all hurtling towards the next sighting of the wildlife so be prepared you're not going to get a personal experience. Some of the jeep drivers are reckless and we would have seen the leopard if a selfish jeep driver hadn't given up waiting and driven off, scaring it away. Having said that, we saw lots of elephants and by staying later in the park we were rewarded by watching then make their way down to the water and go in to bathe. It was wonderful to see the parents take the baby elephant in, and watch as they rolled around in the water. The jeeps are really uncomfortable and there's a lot of hanging around but at the end of the day we got to see elephants in the wild which was marvellous.

We LOVED Wilpattu National Park. So beautiful!  And so much wildlife. We did one half day and two full day safaris - and wished we could have done more. We saw leopards, bears, deer, monkeys, crocodiles, tortoise, and so many wonderful birds! Our driver/spotter - Malith - was so great. It was amazing what wildlife he could find. Thank you Malith for helping us to have such a great experience.

No leopard sighting for us, despite doing a Full Day (11 hours) safari, with lunch supplied, but we still loved the park. Lots of birds mostly for us, but elephants, deer, monitors, crocodiles, buffalo, butterflies, monkeys (look our for them stealing from your jeep if you stop for lunch!) and the biggest damned spider I've ever seen! Expecting leopards can spoil your time at a park. Go along and enjoy the sensation of sharing the environment with any of the animals.

This place is about testing your luck... i'd say i was 90% lucky first off this is a national park with some 130000 hectares of land, don't come thinking that it is a must that you will get to see the famous leopard or bear. I was lucky to see a leopard cub, although sleeping, it was already cool, a bear digging for food, tonnes of variety of bird, i'm already thankful. Book a private jeep so that you won't be cramped with other people fighting for spots to take photos.

A good experience overall, but your enjoyment will depend entirely upon your own attitude‚Ä¶..if you are expecting an interesting drive through varied landscape with the possibility of key wildlife as a bonus, go for it!  You will love it!  If you are anticipating seeing leopards elephants and bears up close, around every corner, you are setting yourself up for disappointment and may be better off at a zoo or safari park.  These are wild animals that live over a vast range, so you can be lucky, or not! We were fortunate to see two sloth bears up close, and while we were lucky enough to watch a leopard walking along a lake shore, it was at a great distance such that my dream of a gorgeous leopard photo, collided with the reality of a small fuzzy quadruped appearing as a spot on my screenüò¢

Great area with wonderful spots and views. We did a 12-hour safari with a friend and photographer who is very familiar with the park. And we were lucky! Three leopards, a sloth bear and elephants! But after 12 hours we were overwhelmed and tired‚Ä¶ but it was worth it.

There are plenty of wild life but couldn't see Elephants but over hundred out side the park. As usual lots of birds . We saw six leopards. Less crowded than of Yala and what we really admire was the coordination of  Jeep drivers, They don't mind to give other jeeps to see leopards, bears etc after about five mints.   It really helps each other and specially the visitors.

We booked a photo safari in Wilpattu National Park. Unfortunately, we didn't have many opportunities to take beautiful animal photos because our jeep driver stormed through the park very quickly. He always seemed to be looking for elephants, so he raced past grazing deer. We had to point out to him that the animals were at the edge of the forest. It's a shame actually. With a few exceptions, birds/peacocks, monitor lizards, water buffalo and deer, we didn't see any other animals. Our conclusion is that this visit took place in the wrong part of the park and was therefore not that nice.

I had been to Minneriya NP almost a decade ago but this was far better. A lot of time was wasted at the administation complex filling out a form. The tour lasted almost four hours. I loved the forest glades that shielded from the sun while our six passenger Toyota negotiated unmade roads including some beach tracks. Not many animals were seen: an elephant and calf bathing, a mongoose at a concrete water basin, a distant leopard sunbaking, sambar and spotted deer plus water buffalo that are common in southeast Asia was all. With birds we saw kingfishers and beeeaters plus numerous smaller birds and waders such as stilts. Butterflies were numerous. There was a toilet stop about 65 per cent into the tour replete with monkeys that steal anything. The driver had good English. His assistant lacked any. Take a hat and water plus sunglasses. Overall for Sri Lanka, a good experience and not too crowded.

There is few operator on this zone for the jeep and guides of different price ranges.  We opted for driver only and we personally felt the entry of the national park was fairly expensive (lkr 11000) for what we have spotted, but  I can‚Äôt compare to any other national park. We were apparently very very lucky to spot a leopard, coyotes, peacock fighting, spotted deerssss, wild boar and giant squirrels. What I like was the different type of terrain and sceneries from the sandy lake to the first lazing by rocks. Recommended for family with older kids or for people who don‚Äôt like hiking.

Favorite park of our trip to Sri Lanka! Incredible flora and fauna, we also had the chance to see 2 leopards (very quickly, but it was a short moment suspended in time!). There are a few jeeps all the same, but it is largely acceptable and we were often alone (the park is large). We had a driver but no naturalist unlike our visit to Lunughamwehera, so if you have the opportunity to have one accompany you I highly recommend as you will learn more about the interbreeding species. We would love to come back next time!

We got a keep through our driver, and 90% of who we saw on the trails seemed to have done the same. The scenery is nice but we only saw some smaller animals like deer, peacocks, etc. Still a good ride. It was afternoon so fewer animals but also less crowded. Like whale watching it‚Äôs a risk, but if you enjoy the scenery (and don‚Äôt mind forking out 40k LKR per head for four hours) it‚Äôs alright. Go for it if you know you‚Äôll enjoy the ride, which it‚Äôs a safe bet you will.

To get the fullest experience I would recommend a two night stay in the area so you can spend the maximum time in this huge wildlife park. Needless to say the vehicle used is a typical 4x4 which gets you through the mud roads and flooded area. Nature is what it is and there is never a guarantee to see anything specific, however the guides have extremely keen eyesight and will stop for photos etc. The prized sighting is that of the elusive leopard and with all the guides looking and communicating hopefully you will sight one as we did. If you are a keen bird watcher you will not be disappointed. If you hope to see elephants here some of the other parks may prove better

On a 19 day tour we visited the park and had a jeep safari with our tour guide along. It really was a good safari around 4 hours of bumping around. Close encounters with the wild life and our driver was expert at spotting animals and birds.

Included as part of our travel itinerary, so no choice but would recommend to avoid if possible. Traveled up from Negombo and arrived in time for 13.00pm booking together with about 20 jeeps travelling. We had to reject our first jeep as it was in a a dreadful condition about 20 hrs old, seat cushions worn out and seat belts not working. Replacement was a little better but not by much. Spent 5 hrs travelling in dirt roads being thrown about with sightings of various birds, monitor lizard and plenty of deer e.g. nothing that creates any excitement. In fact there is no big game here and the whole experience was unrewarding. Total ripoff. You‚Äôll have a better experience in any of the UK wildlife parks at a lot less cost

At the end of December 2023 I was lucky enough to spend 8 hours doing a safari in this beautiful national park. We arrived at 6.30am to take a safari organized by my wonderful Sri Lankan friends. The jeeps are well maintained, seats are really comfortable ( I have done many safari's in different parts of India.) As we left the HQ the various jeeps headed off in different directions so we were alone for almost all of our safari. Our principle focus was birds and the guide was very knowledgeable, we saw 82 species of birds, various mammals including 3 species of deer, water buffalo, elephant & primates etc. We also saw mugger crocodiles, flap shell turtle. No sign of leopards however we were not really looking for them. The driver was great at spotting, stopping and turning off the motor. With just 4 of us on the jeep photography was easy. We experienced so heavy rain which required the side and front curtains to be rolled down. As soon as it stopped the driver would roll them up again. Our group included 2 of us with strong interest in wildlife, and natural areas and i would come back to Wilpattu at every opportunity. Thank you to my friends and to the park staff for an excellent day in nature. It's important to understand that in nature nothing is guaranteed, if you understand that then you will enjoy whatever experience that you get. You can rest assured that the driver/guides will find as much as is possible on any safari as their role is to find and show as much as possible to their passengers in a safe way for both us humans and the animals. Just loved my day.

Definitely less crowded and frantic than Yala and Udawalawe,  however possibly with good reason, as , apart from lots of deer, a few birds and some monkeys at the picnic area, we didn't see any wildlife on our half day tour until finally, on the way back out, we came across about ten jeeps stopped to look at a leopard sleeping under a bush (which we needed binoculars to see). In fact we were told halfway through our tour that to see elephants you need a full day tour because they are in a further away area! Very pleasant but disappointing as had planned our trip around this.

Visiting Wilpattu National Park was an awe-inspiring journey into the heart of nature's magnificence. As an avid wildlife enthusiast, the park's paramount natural importance and diverse ecosystem left an indelible mark on my soul. Beyond its natural allure, Wilpattu National Park has become a gem in Sri Lanka's tourism landscape. The park's responsible tourism initiatives ensure that visitors not only enjoy a breathtaking safari experience but also contribute to the preservation of this natural wonder. The sprawling landscapes of Wilpattu are not just a treat for the eyes but a sanctuary for a myriad of animals. From majestic elephants and elusive leopards to an array of exotic bird species, every moment felt like a scene from a wildlife documentary. In conclusion, Wilpattu National Park is more than just a tourist attraction; it's a testament to the importance of nature conservation. For anyone seeking a harmonious blend of natural beauty, diverse wildlife, and responsible tourism, Wilpattu is an absolute must-visit. It was a truly unforgettable experience that left me in awe of the wonders of our planet. Mammals at Wilpattu National Park: Including Sri Lankan Elephant, Sri Lankan Sloth Bear, Sri Lankan Leopard, Water Buffalo, Sambar and Spotted Deer, Mongoose, Mouse Deer, and Shrew. Reptiles and amphibians at Wilpattu National Park: Including Monitor Lizard, Mugger Crocodile, Common Cobra, Rat Snake, Indian Python, Pond Turtle and the Soft-Shelled Turtle Birdlife at Wilpattu National Park: Including several species of Owl, Tern, Gull, Eagle, Kite, Buzzard, Painted Stork, Sri Lankan Junglefowl, Little Cormorant, Garganey, Pintail, Whistling Teal, Spoonbill, White Ibis, Large White Egret, Cattle Egret and Purple Heron

The park was closed until 2003 due to the Civil War and as of today, it is a highly valued wild life destination for both local and foreign tourists.

Wilpattu is the oldest and largest (1317 sq km) National Park in Sri Lanka and we explored it from the delightful Leopard Trails luxury tented safari camp.  The camp is only a few minutes drive from the National Park‚Äôs entrance gate and our journeys to and from the park were partly taken on the wrong side of the road.   The local rice farmers have worked out that by spreading their newly harvested rice over one carriageway, the rice dries twice as quickly (using the heat attracted by the black tarmac) as traditional methods.  We took three drives (one full day and two half days) which saw us cover a good deal of the park‚Äôs forested, sandy and lake side areas.  It was great to see many animals in their natural habit and spotted deer, water buffalo, jackals and wild boar made regular appearances.  An elephant entertained us by standing in the lake, ripping vast quantities of water plants up, shaking off the mud and munching them for it‚Äôs tea.  There were many species of birds to admire, with sea eagles catching their supper from the lake, serpent eagles and owls staring regally from their tree perches and our favourite, the brightly coloured varieties of bee eaters.  Often our drives seemed like we were driving through snow, as white butterflies settled in mud pools to collect minerals and then burst into blizzard like flight as we passed close by.  A picture postcard position beside the lake was perfect for a sumptuous lunch.  A little drama was added by monkeys watching us closely for the chance of any left overs and us keeping a careful eye on the partly submerged crocodile twenty meters out in the lake.  Further searching revealed many other sightings, even a brief glimpse of a Sloth Bear.  Sadly the key attraction (leopards) remained elusive for everyone

Wilpattu sits a little bit off the regular organised tour circuit, positioned slightly north of the central west coast of the country. It's also Sri Lanka's largest national park. These two factors mean that you'll experience less safari traffic than in Yala or even Kaudulla. Another benefit, if you're lucky enough to discover a leopard or other large animal, is that there is no mobile phone reception so safari guides cannot readily communicate sightings to stimulate a mad dash by everyone within range to share the experience. It's a selfish view, but it paid off for us when we encountered a leopard on a lakeside trail in a more remote part of the park. Our driver slowly reversed the vehicle as our leopard followed us back down the trail for about 15 minutes before padding off into the jungle. We also encountered a Fishing Eagle and Crested Serpent Eagle within telephoto lens range in this park - something we had not been able to do elsewhere. Wilpattu also offers encounters with the usual suspects - water buffalo, land monitors, wild boar, spotted and barking deer, crocodiles and a wide variety of birds.

I was wary of other national parks in Sri Lanka (e.g. Yala, Minneriya) as I had heard they were very busy with jeeps and I really don't enjoy viewing wildlife when you are one of 20 jeeps crowded around - so I thought I would give Wilpattu a try. I did one full-day safari and started at the Eluwankulama entrance - it was quiet when I went, there were no queues and the only other jeep there was carrying the other guests from my hotel. The biggest group of jeeps that I saw at once (aside from at the rest stop) was when a leopard had been sighted in the bushes. At that point there were maybe 6-8 jeeps in the vicinity waiting for the leopard to make an appearance. The leopard did indeed come out and crossed the road in a flash! At other times throughout the day, we passed the occasional other jeep but often went long stretches of time without seeing anyone else which was really nice. The park is vast, a lot of it is wooded and so it felt harder to spot animals for this reason. There are several watering holes and you can see animals drinking around the perimeter. I did see a huge variety of birds, elephants (including a large group just before the entrance/exit to the park - I was the only jeep there), 2 leopards (fleeting / at a distance), monitor lizards, deer, monkeys... The wildlife is fewer and far between compared to other places perhaps, and we did go a couple of hours without seeing any animals at all. When you do spot something though, it feels extra special for this reason. I didn't love the rest stop where I was brought for breakfast / lunch - too many monkeys which steal food and climb into the jeeps. They are afraid of the drivers but certainly not afraid of the tourists. There are basic squat toilet facilities. I would have preferred to have parked near one of the water holes in the park and eaten there instead. Overall, if you go with the right attitude and don't expect a zoo - you will enjoy Wilpattu.

We were staying in a hotel in Anuradhapura and left at 5:00am to visit the park, I think it was about an hours drive, and when we arrived we were surprised at just how many vehicles there were here and we queued to enter the park proper at 6;35pm in a bit of a convoy. We'd already seen a mongoose cross the road before we got to the park and at the entrance on a bird feeder there was a beautifully tailed Ceylon Paradise Flycatcher, so it was a good start. It turned out to be a very good trip for birdlife. I'm no expert but we saw kingfishers, Junglefowl, painted storks, peafowl, woolly necked storks, a great thick knee, bee eaters by the dozen, and plenty more, including an in-flight white bellied sea eagle and a crested serpent eagle that happily posed in a tree by the track. As for mammals and reptiles.... whilst we didn't spot any elephants, we saw monitor lizards, crocodiles, monkeys, mongoose, chipmunks, deer and water buffalo, but the highlight for us was that we were lucky enough to see (and see very well) a leopard just prowling in the undergrowth about 15 or 20 feet off the track. Sadly it was obscured by foliage so I couldn't get a clear photograph of the leopard, but will always remember just how big and powerful he looked. So all in all had a very good first safari. We had been a little concerned at the beginning that we'd just be following jeep after jeep but although it was busier than I would have liked we still saw a good deal and felt it was an interesting trip. The breakfast stop at the lake appears to be an automatic place to pause for a break, but be warned, don't leave anything loose especially food as the very knowing monkeys here will snatch it away before you have a chance to blink and they just love hotel pack ups.

We did 2 safaris at Wilpattu. One was an afternoon safari and one was an all day safari. Wilpattu is a big park and there are less roads than at Yala, but there are also a lot less jeeps, and for much of our wildlife viewing we were on our own. During our afternoon safari we watched a sloth bear feeding from a termite nest very close to the road. We were able to sit there for around 20 minutes and during that time we were joined by maybe half a dozen other jeeps - a complete contrast to Yala where around 30 jeeps were competing for a view of a sloth bear which was much further away from the road. We saw lots of animals and birds. We didn't see a leopard but we saw plenty of evidence that they were around - lots of very recent footprints in the sand - it's down to luck whether you actually see one or not, but the chance is obviously increased by the number of safaris you undertake. There is a place where they stop for lunch and breakfast where there is also a basic hole in the ground type toilet. Beware of all the monkeys there, who will steal your food at any opportunity! As expected it is a very bumpy ride in the jeep and my husband suffered a bit as he has some joint problems - especially during the all day safari, which lasted from 6.15am to 6.00pm. However the advantage of the all day safari is that they can take you much further into the park, away from any other jeeps. This park is not for kids who will easily get bored - but it is a genuinely immersive wildlife experience.

We had a great trip around the great Wilpattu National Park. Perhaps we were lucky, but we chose the park for it's actual wildlife, which means you cannot be sure what you get to see during your visit. The is definitely preferred over the captive or sedated animals you may find in other countries.

Reading many reviews here, I must conclude that many hotels nearby the park who organize the Jeep tours are scamming the tourists, which is really sad. We stayed at The Backwaters and organized our safari trip with them and found them to be very trustworthy. They charged us LKR 6500 (Feb 2019), for a private Jeep fitting up to 6 people with an extra guide to sit with us. The Jeep and entrance fee must be paid in the local currency. Seeing a leopard or a bear is up to luck, and we unfortunately didn‚Äôt see these animals. We came close to spotting a leopard in the bushes but mostly the guide spotted it and could take a picture of it for us. The bushes are really dense so you have to be really lucky or early to spot a leopard walking up to you on the roads or in an open space. We did a half day safari starting from 6:30 to about 11am. By the end of it we were pretty beat. So maybe it's more advisable to do a morning and evening safari on two separate days if you wish. Bring a jacket and wear light long pants as the Jeep is open (windy) and the morning air gets quite cold. The drive in is through a long road of dense bush land which might be a bit boring if you can't spot anything. There are small ponds where you might spot crocodiles. Our favorite spots were the open spaces with a sort of marshland or watering hole / lakes which look like a dreamland. There you can spot heards of deers, and if you're lucky like us, a large elephant swimming through the water! Simply magical! We also spotted wild boars, many birds, a turtle, a ferret and monkeys. Of course we wished we'd seen more large animals but it is up to luck really. We would rate the park more highly if it would have had more plentiful, and better maintained washrooms which are a basic necessity for an area which invites tourists to visit it. There is no soap, the toilet is a squatting toilet which you can't even flush, so you can imagine the smell. Please bring your own toilet paper and hand soap... And of course someone has to invariably take a dump just on the side of the toilet hole itself. Why??? If you can, use the washroom near the ticketing office and avoid drinking till you're about to leave the park again.

We recently visited Anuradhapura and ventured across to Wilpattu for a safari.  We decided to eschew Yala as it has a reputation of being very busy, so can't comment on that, but Wilpattu isn't as quiet as we expected - even if there are only a dozen or so vehicles, you'll still end up seeing the same cars time and again as you search endlessly for wildlife!  The bush is pretty thick in places in Wilpattu, so spotting stuff can be pretty tricky at times, particularly if your driver is driving at a quicker pace that you'd like!  We started early - we were in the park by 6.15am - and it was cold, particularly with the windchill when driving - if you go early, do yourself a favour and take some warm layers with you!  We did spot quite a few things on our day safari - lots of birdlife, and quite a few mammals and reptiles too.  We weren't lucky enough to see a leopard on this occasion, but we did see a sloth bear late in the day and there's clearly a grapevine as within 10 minutes of spotting it there were about 10 vehicles around us!  We noticed quite a few vehicles had separate guides while we just had a driver - haveing done other safaris this concerned us, as normally a separate guide is a good thing (we re-organised our safari late due to issues with our previously arranged trip so had little choice!) and while we managed OK in the end I'd suggest a separate guide would be better.  It can be a very long day though - we were in at 6.15am and left the park at about 5.30pm, having been batttered and bruised from the drive in the meantime.  Still, it was well worth it - while we seemed to spend more time driving round to find stuff than we'd have liked, we did see a decent quantity and variety of animals in the end, and came away feeling pretty happy about it (probably the sloth bear siting helped!)

Thus, a team of 5 including me traveled early in the morning, and did reach the main entrance by 09:00 am, since we made a wrong turn, which delayed reaching our destination. Since we traveled after rains during mid December in 2018, the weather was cool and comfortable. My biggest aim was to spot a leopard and a sloth bear this time as I did not get the chance of spotting one the previous time I traveled. There were only few jeeps inside the park from the time we entered until around 03:00 pm in the afternoon, and as such we had the opportunity enjoy the nature and its beauty in more relaxed moods. We did spot a variety of birds, and then many deer roaming about. We did see the most often seen lonely elephant who enjoys reeds that grow, and did manage to see a single leopard cub, who spend about 20 mts traveling in front of our jeep, without being disturbed. I hoped that I would see a bear and many crocodiles, but I was not lucky enough to see them. We left the park entrance around 06:30 pm on the same day and headed to Colombo and reached Colombo around 10:30 pm. Though we expected to be tired, non of felt tired after a full day of traveling and spending inside wilderness. Hope to travel again to see many more animals to Wilpattu National Park as soon as possible. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g304132-d2706501-r645311122-Wilpattu_National_Park-Anuradhapura_North_Central_Province.html#

We went with zero expectations of seeing a leopard and were pleasantly surprised to see one at the end of the day.  Keep in mind - this isn't a zoo so you can't control what animals make an appearance. I would definitely recommend a visit to this park!

This was my second time visiting this park, so many animals in their nature habitat. Similar to Yala, another great park. This one was in the northwest part of the country where there are many sites, ancient cities and a calm ocean.

if you want see elephants in their natural habitat this is one of the best places to do it in Sri Lanka.

The driver was very good at spotting animals and birds...The highlight of course was seeing the sloth bear who put his head out of the dense undergrowth so we got a good look at his snout and then ambled back in to the jungle. We went during the rainy season so the luxuriant foliage prevented us from seeing many animals unless they actually came on to the road. But this was exactly what the spotted deer did! The darling little fawns happily played while we watched them! It was like being in a film with Bambi & Fern! The stag with huge antlers looked really majestic. We also saw many peacocks, painted stork, eagles and the red wattled lapwing heard it's characteristic cry "Did heeeeee do it?"! Altogether it was an amazing family trip which created lifetime memories! Don't forget to bring a good camera with a wildlife lens if possible! But if you do forget...the Wilpattu Tree House hires them out.

My wife and I were staying in Colombo on business but had one day off, so we booked a trip to Wilpattu, the only major park within a reasonable travelling distance. This was with Sri Lanka Day Tours. It was still a long drive but we had an excellent driver and she included a lunch stop on the way.  We had booked an afternoon tour and arrived a little early, but the driver phoned the guide and within 10 minutes the 4x4 truck arrived.  We had a four hour tour deep into the park, seeing two large birds of prey just a few metres away, three species of deer, a mongoose - all at close quarters - and many water birds near the lakes and pools.  At the furthest pools we saw hundreds of flying foxes - large bats - hanging from trees, giving a "different world" appearance to the area and a mugger crocodile, very still with just its snout above the water.  We started back then just as light started to fade, a leopard, just 10m away.  We watched it in the bush and walking across the track ahead, for about 15 minutes.  A brilliant round up to the day. Two small gripes - the guide could have been better at pointing out and naming some of the smaller birds - though he identified over 30 species - and the company could have been clearer at the start about what pick up time was needed to get us there in time for the tour.  The day overall was about 13 hours, which was pushing it.  Still, an excellent trip overall which we will remember for many years, and at a very reasonable price.

Panikkar Villu Bungalow, Wilpattu National Park. This is a tough one. Staying at a Wildlife Conservation Department bungalow inside a national park is at best compared to camping out, except you have a roof over your head. Let‚Äôs list out what you don‚Äôt have: Charging facilities for camera batteries. Wi-fi Refrigeration Mobile phone signal Easy access to groceries If you‚Äôve never stayed in a WCD bungalow before, you‚Äôd be in for a shock. You have to take everything you need for the duration of your stay into the park. Everything. From water to toilet amenities to linen and towels. You have to plan your meals and buy what you need to make them. And not just for you and your party but for at least 3 other adults - the tracker, driver and caretaker cum cook. The Wildlife Conservation Department say you don‚Äôt have to feed their employees, but practically this is impossible. How can you not feed the people looking after your well-being in the middle of a jungle? So don‚Äôt go stay at a WCD Bungalow if you don‚Äôt have someone who can coordinate everything for you, between your party and the WCD bungalow stay. That would be a disaster waiting to happen. As is was, with all our planning, on or third day there we were down to our last two and a half litres of water, which was cutting it a bit fine, in my book. The thing is, if any of what you‚Äôve read up to now has thrown you off staying inside a national park - a jungle - you‚Äôre not the type of person who should be there in the first place. The Bungalows inside the national parks run by the WCD are for people who enjoy the thrill of a perfect capture of a leopard walking right up to them. Or observing an elephant chase off errant safari vehicles from the comfort of the bungalow verandah. Or being the early birds in a wildlife park, with the best chance of  spotting a wide variety of birds and beasts. Or being the last people to finish a safari for the day, driving up to you bungalow exactly at 6:00pm at which time all human activity in the park has to be confined to the WCD bungalows that are occupied. It‚Äôs an experience that, if you could make happen, you should have at least once in your life. Most people forfeit this experience for hiring a safari Jeep outside the park and driving into the park for a three hour excursion. This is understandable because when you‚Äôre on holiday the last thing on your mind would be meal planning and buying groceries - say nothing of the time constraints forced upon you by packaged tours. This method of seeing the park works too.  But you‚Äôd never know that exhilarating feeling of seeing a Sloth Bear less than ten meters away from your back door at 8:45pm, having his dinner  (fruits from a tree in the garden. You can not, ever, feed the animals). And then there are the birds and beasts. Each sighting of an animal or a bird is unique and it doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre in the park for a drive in and out safari or staying in the park at a bungalow. There‚Äôs always that sense of awe when you‚Äôre tracker leads your vehicle along the path that he thinks the leopard would take - and he turns out to be right! A word about the WCD personnel here. You can‚Äôt enter any national park without a tracker. This is the person who works for the department who has a twofold job. The first and arguable the most important is to see that you and your party behave themselves in the park, not ‚Äúspooking‚Äù the wildlife. The second is to show you as much of the wildlife in the park as possible. For this the tracker has to know not only the geography of the park, but the psychology of the animals in the park. A good tracker is essential to a good experience as much as good planing is. We had a good tracker. We spotted eight individual leopards in two and a half days. We also saw Elephant, Water Buffalo and Bear, Barking and Spotted Deer, Jackal, Wild Boar and over 25 different species of birds of which two were endemic and one sighting was absolutely unique - a juvenile Serpent Eagle practising a kill on twigs on the ground. The only animal the tracker didn‚Äôt show us was the bear. The bear visited us himself! The safari jeep and driver we hired because without that combo, one of the party would have had to drive. This of course would have meant one of us would be concentrating on the road and not on seeing things. Not having to do that was a good call on our part. Do I recommend a stay at the Panikkar Villu Bungalow? The answer is an unqualified yes. No matter what your have to do to prep for your stay there, it‚Äôs worth it.

This national park and wildlife reserve is probably not as well known as some others and I understand it was only created about 6 years ago following this area being off bounds during the civil war. As a result, much wildlife has been left to its own devices, but like many others, licences jeeps and drivers are available for hire. Our cost 8,000rps each and was designed to be one of the longest trips. You can negotiate shorter trips for less cost down to about 4,000rps each. Our Jeep driver was very happy to stop and check things out and during a 4 hour trip, we managed to see most of Sri Lanka's wildlife starting with a smaller adult bull elephant grazing on the trees about 500 metres from the park entrance. During the trip we also saw crocodiles, Mongoose, sand deer, spotted deer, water buffalo, monkey and many birds which thankfully our quite could identify for us. We had begun the trip at 2pm and we're lucky enough to get a call that a leopard had been spotted - quite close to the entrance again - so we rushed for half an hour to get to this spot and were very lucky indeed to catch sight of this beautiful creature. Apparently there are 12 leopards living in this area and with 2 babies this year the population is at least steady, although pressure on space can lead to conflict with the local population. The ride was bumpy and dusty, but the experience was wonderful and it was an inspired idea to create this further wildlife reserve. We have so enjoyed our opportunities to see the wildlife and watching as these creatures shyly come to the water holes and lakes in the late afternoon has been a real privilege. Don't miss an opportunity at some stage to get out into the countryside and the skill of the Jeep drivers both managing to traverse the tracks, know their way round the parks, work out where best to see the animals and communicate with each other, was very impressive.
