The vehicle was very comfortable and the scenery is interesting. We were lucky to have a good cab driver with excellent animal tracking ability. We spent about 10 hours in the jungle and we could see more than 40 types of animals including elephants, dears, monitors, fox, peacocks, jungle fowls, crocodiles, Monkeys, Deers, a playful baby bear, eagles, a lot of birds and in the end the mother bear) heaps of raptors and horn bills, plus elephant, various types of birds. This park is full of elephants, monkeys, deer, Wild Boar, Birds, Sri Lankan Bear, Crocodiles and many more.  We were lucky enough to spot a leopard in situ as well. We were gifted  in spotting  an elephant taking a bath in the marshes. We observed both the park department jeeps as well as private vehicles but all the drivers seemed to be in touch so that when a sighting was made, the other vehicles were able to coordinate to maximize sightings. Our driver was so brilliant, making sure we didn't miss a thing and we saw some amazing wildlife and had every opportunity to take great shots of the things we saw. We saw more than 100 elephant at the same time it was really amazing experience  with our driver and a very friendly and knowledgeable guide. Wilpathu national park is beautiful and is full of many types of animals. I recommend you to visit and get the excitement.

We were in the park on 13th and 15th April afternoons. Saw Bear, Leopard, lots of Deer, a few Elephants and many species of birds. It was wet and gloomy which in turn had its plus and minus side. The cooler climate meant that animals came out of the jungle and could be seen. The minus was that photography was challenging and by 15th entry from our side of Eluvankulam was impossible and we had to go a long way round.
The best park in Sri Lanka! Much less crowded than Yala, with a greater sightings of Leopards. In my three night stay I was fortunate to spotted 6 all together. Highly recommended!
Good place to visit. Lucky to see a leopard,an elephant , deer, peacock, eagles, butterflies .. Bit rainy.. but good.. Better to visit it in the morning  or in the evening.. not in day time ...

We did two safari trips at 14:00 and 06:30 the following day. The park was very busy, at numerous points we were in a convoy of 5 or 6 jeeps which doesn't make for the most enjoyable experience, especially the way the drivers jostle, reverse and drive alongside the animals to get the best views. The park is very nice, there's a toilet station in the middle to stop and have a break. We did see a lot of animals here which was what most people obviously go for! We saw a leopard, sloth bear and elephant (each from about 4 metres) which was a great experience. Unfortunately as mentioned, for most of those there were also 6 other noisy jeeps with us!

It was a very enjoyable 4 days and 3 nights inside the Wilpattu Park with friends and family. 6 different Leopards, 2 Bears, 3 Elephants and many more wildlife. If you can access online booking its best if you can stay inside the park for few nights. Our friends who was first time visitors to Wilpattu National park was very lucky to see multiple leopards at a very close distance with 2 Bears (mother & cub)

Comfortable seats for a rocky ride, although I tore my trousers on a sharp edge.  As to be expected the driver had good eyes and we were introduced to bird life that we had not seen before.  Other than that it was crocs, deer and buffalo.  Apparently bears had been spotted that day but unfortunately not by us.  We didn‚Äôt see leopard either but were not disappointed as we have been lucky in that respect in Africa.  On the whole our African safaris have been teeming withwildlife and therefore this was not as exciting but we are still glad that we did it.

We absolutely loved our stay at Wilpattu Treehouse and our full day safari at Wilpattu National Park. If it‚Äôs mandatory to see leopards this may not be the place for you...go to Yala or Botswana. They‚Äôre hard to see and it‚Äôs blind luck but a lot of people spotted them and the park itself is stunning and full of other wildlife. Elephants, crocodiles, deer, mongoose, monitor lizards, turtles, peacocks and a huge variety of beautiful birds. The treehouse is right at the gate which is a great location. We stayed with people who had seen leopards with cubs and sloth bears the same day so it‚Äôs not something that never happens. Highly recommend.

We set off very early (5am) to visit the national park and we were rewarded. We were very impressed on first sight as it seems very well organised and there is an educational aspect to the visit. The guides were incredible, they had eyes like hawks. They would see stuff in the bush it took us ages to see but saw it we did. I just liked the feel of this place, it was like the animals were respected and not just there for our entertainment, it's proper wild. We saw plenty. Just two elephants, but they are wild and don't just show up because we're there. Lots of birds we'd never seem before along with deer, lizards, crocodiles, lots of monkeys. Highly recommend it. The only thing that was disappointing was the gift shop was closed when we were leaving and we would have bought stuff there as it looked good quality.

Wherever we go on safari, I don't  like the question:' so what did you see?'. Because if I were to say: we saw amazing plants, eagles, beeeaters..., people just switch off. In Africa, they only want to hear if you have seen the big 5, here in Wilpattu, wildlife has been reduced to the Big 3. That makes me a bit sad because surely all of nature is to be appreciated? The bad reviews here baffle me: how can you review a forest? I seem to understand that if people see a leopard, they give it a high rating, otherwise not so... well Wilpattu is not a zoo but a vast and sometimes densely overgrown Wilderness. I loved the wildness of it, the lakes full of Lillies, the trees... we only saw a glimpse of a leopard and a lone elephant far away but we saw an eagle a meter away from use, colourful green bee-eaters right close, monkeys, deer, fighting lizards, storks, peacocks, a giant squirrel and many birds. Isn't that amazing? In my book, it is. We got the impression lots of people come here for the day from the beaches and they expect to have the animals shown to them on demand. Shame I guess because I think this park is lovely!

it was the 1st of December and got a leave to discover again my favorite national park in Sri Lanka. started the day with a full day safari. there were some small rain during the weekend, but i'm confident on the sightings. we were searching for the predator.  spotted some foot marks already, but no sightings. we visited the historic Kuveni palace during the safari and then continue it to the beautiful Nelumwila. Suddenly our jeep friend stopped the jeep and showed us something. we checked it with our binos. it was the 1st sighting of rare migrant Black capped kingfisher. i knew this was a golden opportunity. filled my camera with some beautiful images. i was still searching for the leapard. but there were no sightings yet. however we decided to check some further places to catch him. this was the last few hours of our safari. finally our jeep driver stopped the vehicle near the bend and drove the jeep quickly reverse. There was a leopard near the road. i havent met him earlier. He was the super star at Nelumwila.

Great park with lots of wildlife and the most amazing range of local Sri Lankan birds; all so beautiful. I chose to come here rather than the very popular and touristy Yala national park and glad I did. It was less crowded and still had lots of amazing wildlife to see. Highlights for me was seeing a gorgeous young leopard on the roadside and a land monitor lizard eating another lizards prized eggs from a hole in the ground.

We have visited several National Parks in Sri Lanka and were slightly disappointed with this one. We drove in the jeep through the trees and couldn‚Äôt see a great amount of wildlife. The driver tried hard to get us to see a leopard as two other jeeps had seen one, but we were not so lucky. There is more to see in the other parks.

Had an amazing safari around the park and saw lots of wildlife including - a bull elephant, baby leopard, sloth bear, turtle, monkeys, peacock and pea hens, spotted deer and samba deer, kingfishers, bee eaters, hawk eagles, serpent hawks and many other birds. The 4x4‚Äôs were very good at getting around and the drivers where very talented at spotting animals deep in cover or high up in trees.

Sorry to hear that others didn‚Äôt see much but we really enjoyed it. On our 4 hour trip we saw a leopard, monkeys, monitor lizards, crocs, mongoose, grizzle giant squirrel, water buffalo, samba deer, spotted deer and SO many bird species. Our guide had a bird book too which we really appreciated. Wouldn‚Äôt do it again but well worth it

I was here with two of my friends for full day safari. Start the journey at 6.30 am. It was a full of lucky day. We saw bears elephants and 3 leapords also. Other than many wild animals and lot of birds. It is better to take enough foods and water when you are in full day safari. And please take care of your safari driver too. Some of the visitors do not care of them. I think it is the best park in sri lanka to see many wild animals.
Have good views/perspective from the 4 x 4 safari vehicles which bounce along the dirt tracks, stopping every now and then to show you animals of interest. Quite enjoyable and fun.

Our first wildlife trip in SL and pretty disappointed. Once you get to the park, there is a very long drive to get anywhere with very limited wildlife. Our drive lasted 5 hours. We are well used to African game drives and understand that animals do not perform to order! All we saw was a few bird species, monitors, spotted deer, 1 water buffalo and 1 elephant. Pretty disappointing - sorry.

In 3 jeeps, our group took to the tacks and how the drivers spot so many interesting birds and animals as they go is amazing!  They always stopped for us to get photos where possible and we all enjoyed the time immensely.  We did not see any elephants of leopard, but several land monitors, eagles, bee eaters, flycatchers, monkeys and so much more.
Compared to Minneriya, which is too crowded with jeeps chasing around after the elephant herds, Wilpattu is tight and compact with a great lakeside breakfast stop and plenty of birds.
it can get a bit busy in the park, but if you get the morning start, say 0630 at start things are very quiet and you see lots of birds and with luck: 2 elephants, a leopard, etc
We did one late afternoon drive and a full day one meaning we got to see a lot more of the huge park, with both man made and natural lakes.

A very good park with lots of diversity. We were fortunate to see Leopards, but it always a great experience. The park had few Elephants while we were there as they had moved to other areas as part of the travel cycle. Saw lots of Raptors and many birds including plenty of Jungle Fowl.

Great park teeming with wildlife (more birds than animals though), do come with a pair of binoculars, plenty of water and food, and do arrive early (gate opens at 6.30 am and queues form quickly). You'll need to hire a jeep and very preferably a guide/naturalist who can point out the wildlife to you. A must-visit park if you are a wildlife lover!

‚ÄúWilpattu national park‚Äù, is an hour drive away from the city of Anuradhpura. Named after the hundreds of ‚Äúwillus‚Äù (lakes), In Wilpattu: the largest national park in Sri Lanka, a range of wildlife can be eye witnessed. Popular among them are the families of leopards and the Wild Bear who cross road near your safari jeep trucks. Apart from that, herds of deer, dancing peacocks, several bird species who are inherent to Sri Lanka. If you prefer a day ride in Wilapptu, visit ‚ÄúKudirmalai‚Äù in the national park, a scenic beach overlooking the Gulf of Mannar.

Very scenic experience. Our visit here included 5 adults and 1 4yo child. I recommend a full day safari (starting at 06:00, with a lunch break, and ending at 18:00). Strongly recommend taking at least 2 large bottles (6l) of water, along with lunch (as you will have lunch within the park - for a full day safari). You may also like to take sunglasses. If you are going on the safari with a jeep that has a roof (like ours), you wouldn't need caps. But do note that it could get a bit dusty during the dry season. Wear light clothes, and travel with less things in hand! We signed up with Asinka for taking us on the safari (+94776720162). He is a very friendly guy. But do note that he understands only basic English.

column7: Playa del Carmen, Quintana Roo, Mexico
column11: Me and my friend thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Wilpattu, we got to see lots and lots of different bird species, 2 different species of monkeys ( and lots of them), an elephant, lots of deer, a wild boar, a monitor lizard, some stoats, a huge serpent eagle and much more. We didn't get to see the sloth bears or leopards, but if we knew we would see them then that would take away half the fun, this is not a zoo or a zoo/ safari park. This is animals being allowed to behave as they would have done before we took over, if you are lucky you will see something nice, if not just enjoy the scenery, it's beautiful.

If you want to spot leopards I highly recommend a full day safari in place of a 3 hour safari as you increase the chance of spotting one. The Jeep cost for a full day safari is Rs. 8,000/- You need to tell your hotel or guesthouse to provide breakfast and lunch for you and the safari driver. A full day safari is from 6am to 6pm. Due to the dense Forrest it is difficult to spot birds and very few birds are there compared to Yala.  Eagles are famous there as well as deer and wild boar. If you are lucky you might spot a sloth bear or an elephant. I recommend you go in a Japanese Mitsubishi or Toyota 4WD cabs the Indian Bolero cabs make a big engine noise scaring animals away. The best part about this park is that there are no phone signals so there are no safari jeeps speding and racing inside the park.

We had a full day safari and it was brilliant. We were really lucky and saw 3 leopards, an elephant, monkeys, lizards, numerous birds including several eagles, water buffalo, deer and some crocodiles. What stood out though was the scenery from thick forest to beach areas around some of the lakes. I've seen many negative comments about doing a full day safari but we really enjoyed ours. Later in our trip we also did Minneriya but they had a totally different feel to each other and seeing both was great.

This national park is not as commercial as others yet. The whole experience was good. The park is rather large so we managed to cover only a bit of it but still managed to spot a leopard. Not a bad way to spend the day in nature.

Great full day safari, we saw three leopards, elephants, many spotted and samba deer and birds without the crowds of Yala. We had great stay at Wilpattu House which is very close to the west entrance to the park.

The park itself is amazing. The fauna also. Unfortunately, we did not spot any leopard, but.... That's like it, we can't always be lucky. Totally worth it the 16 hours round trip from Colombo and waking up at 5 am anyway ‚ò∫Ô∏è

column7: La Fortuna de San Carlos, Costa Rica
column11: I visited with friends and we enjoyed wonderful tented accommodation in a very peaceful area of the National Park. Nothing was too much trouble for the staff on site who looked after us like royalty and provided us with wonderful food at mealtimes. We ate under the stars whilst enjoying first class service. We spent the maximum amount of time we could on safari with early starts and full days out on the jeep. We saw amazing wildlife, beautiful birds and butterflies and best of all, a number of leopards. Our driver, Dinendya was amazing and along with our guide, Dumindu, had eagle-eyes which meant we missed nothing. I would highly recommend a visit. Don‚Äôt expect the ‚Äúbig 5‚Äù, but instead something with a touch of class and delight.
We had an excellent day. Spotted lots of wildlife. Watched one male leopard for 45 mins, saw a female also later. Guide excellent, very few jeeps in the park.

organization and  company, we book they good. I I will write Generally Problem about the park most of the driver can‚Äôt speak English. They don‚Äôt realize we are on they habitat.. they just drive around park any speed Would be nice if they knew about how to behive the Animals. It‚Äôs not really safari we just afraid them today by trucks.
Very beautiful national park many variety of wild life. Elephants, deer.Sambhar. wild boar.Leopold and many birds not blocked by safari jeeps

This is a vast, beautiful, unspoiled park.  It made me so happy to see the animals living undisturbed by people and in their natural habitat.  It is a little more challenging to see them but great that they are being respected.

My husband and I had a very disappointing experience hear at the park .After spending 3 hours touring the park we only saw Birds ü¶Ö dear two monkeys üêí and a lizard ü¶é No sign of anything else I realise there‚Äôs no guarantee of seeing any of the big five but a long day with no rewards

We were there at a bad time. It was heavy rain and our jeep let the rain in! There were no elephants, leopards but we did see lots of deer including spotted and samba. The birds were the highlight with wonderful colours.

We had a jeep that was not great in the rain! It leaked!! Unfortunately the rain impacted on the animal sightings so we saw no elephants or sloth bears or leopards. Lots of deer including spotted deer and Samba. Birds were the highlight with lots of beautiful birds to see.
From mongoose through iguana, various deer there was enough to maintain interest. The bird life - jungle fowl, green bee-eater etc was stunning
Thrilling experience with superb landscaping and large natural water pools and lot of wild life in scenic beautiful backgrounds..
Take your Helm‚Äôs Guide to Birds from Sri Lanka!  You‚Äôll be amazed at how many different types of birds you‚Äôll see in a day.

We arrived at the park at 6am which is opening time. The jeeps are fine and the park driver  good however the guide that joined us did not introduce himself or tell us what we might see etc. on our drive. Lots of birds pointed out to us and a book used in case we didn‚Äôt understand. The Jeep stopped to allow time for photos. Lots of deer, only one elephant and sadly no sloth bear or leopards. On return to the entrance the guide just left the vehicle no goodbye etc. This visit was very impersonal and did not impress our Sri Lankan driver either who accompanied us. I cannot recommend this trip.

we started from colombo around 2 o clock and reached wilpattu by 5.15 am. its always recommended to do early morning safari which starts at 6 .00 am. we managed to spot 2 leopards at very close range. apart from that elephants and many kind of birds were spotted on that day. its always advisable to book a full day safari if you really want to spot leopards and other wild animals. sloth bears is spotted mostly in the evening.

What a surprise when I never knew till the visit that Wilpathu western boundary is the Mannar Sea .known as Kudiramale Point . From top of hill at this place had  spectacular view of sea-.breadth taking. Legend says Thambapanni - why the land was orange - copper sand and soil in mostly of surrounding.( not the Kabok). So understood why termed Thambapanni, as the place Prince Vijaya foot in to Sri Lanka. The remnants of Queen Kuveni's Palace is little far and the land had orange soil and sand . Bravo Mother Lanka for your Nature's beauty the Pearl of Indian Ocean

Only a few birds to see. Disapointing. No leapard, no beer. An  Other  jeep Saw a leapard but they do not tell the other jeeps. there is no communication  between  the rangers. So big chance you Will see nothing. You pay a lot of money for it.
Very good park to see leopards and sloth bears. Elephants are more difficult. Not too crowded, much less than Yala...

We had a full day tour in the park and it was amazing. The landscape itself is pretty and changes from jungle to dry areas to lakes where the animals come to drink and with a lot of wetland birds. We got really lucky with the amount of animals and different animals we saw. We spotted a leopard in the morning, and an elephant and bear in the afternoon. Besides that lot of deers, birds and other a animals.

The 4x4s were good, the location and scenery were good, the animals we saw were good. Things here were good but nothing special. The range of animals was not vast, the illusion animals remained elusive and the common animals them being deer were around almost every corner and so used to the 4x4s that they remained really close but actually I see deer that close all the time in the UK Some of the birds were exotic and some good pictures were had. The crocodiles were evident but not big cats as we had expected so not really a let down. Evidence of elephants was everywhere but alas not were seen. The odd lizard crossed our path but actually the experience was a tad underwhelming.

Very expensive place to visit, $150 usd for a full day with two people, and we barely saw anything. Not that I blame this park for the lack of sightings, I understand it's a luck thing, but the price should reflect this better. The park also had no rubbish bins (despite asking you to not drop rubbish?) And the toilets were very basic squat toilets and there were only two in the whole park. (also with no rubbish bins!) Seems like with all the entry fee money it should be better run!

I loved this place!!!! Unfortunately, i went on a half day safari which I regretted, a full day is more appropriate in my opinion. The park is very big, and there is a wide variety of animals. We saw plenty of birds, deer, buffaloes, some elephants, boars, jackals and yes, the amazing leopards. The part I liked most is the fact that it is less touristic as compared to other parks in Sri Lanka, therefore not so many jeeps. also, given the fact that there is no phone reception in the park, guides cannot call one another and advise where the so and so animals are seen, so all is at the mercy of Mother Nature.
We were lucky enough to have a driver who was great at tracking the animals. We were lucky enough to spot 4 leopards in the one day and it was overall a really lovely experience.

The terrain in this park is quite different to the usual jungle one would expect here.  However it was delightful to see something different.  Our driver and guide were excellent and they were quick to point out the different birds and animals. Sadly we saw no elephants but perhaps the middle of a drought is not the best time to visit a game park!  The area is suffering badly. Nevertheless it was a great experience and I would happily return.

Our first safari experience. Booked a half day tour, which allowed us to cross through the park for about 4 hours. Due to the many small lakes the park on it's own is beautiful! We saw many birds and butterflies, many reindeers (even one at a small break time that seemed to like people, allowed us to take several pictures from just half a meter distance and even followed us when we walked back to the jeep). Unfortunately we only saw 1 elephant and no leopards, but it was still worth it.

We enjoyed our safari, well worth the time. Lots of spotted deer and birds and some Elephants. Our tour guid recommend it rather than do two safaris at Udawalawe. Very good advise for us.The terrain was completely differently and very interesting lots of lakes. It was a very peaceful visit with not herds of other people.

We stayed just outside the park and took a full day safari, 6 am to 6 pm, so we could get to the interior. It was a long hot day, and the morning was the best time. There is just one place where you can get out of the vehicle for picnic and toilet. Watch out for monkeys and biting ants here! We saw wild boar, an elephant, wild buffalo, monkeys, deer, crocodiles, monitor lizards and a beautiful leopard who we watched for half an hour. Birds included serpent eagle, fish owl, fish eagle, painted stork, stilts, jungle fowl, bee eaters, and kingfishers.

Wilpattu National Park is a must for animal and wilderness lovers. Aside for the BIG ticket sites of Leopard and Sloth Bear you will see plenty of unique bird life and field game.  Of course if there is a special sighting be prepared for a crush of safari vehicles. Choose a good company to experience the park with like Leopard Safaris or stay as close as you can to entrance to avoid the long queues first thing in the morning.

This is relatively small park by USA standard. One must hire a local safari jeep to get into the park, and a park ranger must sit in the jeep too. Because it is relatively small, you will meet many other jeeps, and because your pay to the jeep driver is fixed so he will try to get back home ASAP, not try to find you the best spot to observe the animals. Again, it is a small park and very dry often so don't expect to find as many animals as in Africa or as in India where land for tiger is more futile.

Is a safari, then all depends on the lucky. We could see eagles, crocodiles, "bambi's", a very kind of birds, buffalos and a LEOPARD. The biggest than the guide has ever seen in the safari. The tour has been very funny and we want to give thanks to our driver by Bobby Safari Wilpattu

This is Sri Lanka's biggest National Park which unlike Yala NP does not close in September. It boasts birds, deer and the elusive leopard and sloth bear which is what everyone wants to see. When we went they hadn't had rain for over a year and the park was parched with little water in the usual watering holes. The park authorities had stopped full day safaris to allow the animals a chance to get what water there was without the hoards of jeeps that ply the very limited tracks.... we did an evening and early morning safari and saw lots of birds, deer and crocodile noses in the evening, the highlight being a leopard viewing but nothing bar a couple of deer in the morning. There are around 150 leopards and 200 sloth bears in the park so it really is down to luck if one decides to walk out in front of you. It was good fun in the jeeps but I suspect that unless it rains l'm not sure how long the authorities will keep it open, they close evening drives for a week before we visited .
Park itself is tremendous with lots of wildlife (Mostly birds). Did get the chance to spot a sloth bear for a few seconds. Amazing scenery with beautiful villus. Good place to be if you love nature

Wilpattu is the largest national park in Sri Lanka, but with less number of jeeps. When you compare with other national parks, Wilpattu is less touristic but with a considerable amount of leopard density (lesser than Yala). However, if you plan to make a safari at a less crowded national park, this is what you are looking for. Cheers - Feel Special.

We were incredibly lucky on safari as we saw a sloth bear only a couple of metres away and they are rare. We also saw a leopard by the water-hole. There were a lot of deer and birds and monkeys too. There were other safari jeeps but unlike Kaudalla where we visited later in the holiday we were not constantly surrounded by other people. Our guide Didi was fantastic and very knowledgeable. Watch the monkeys at the rest point. They come into the jeeps scavenging for food. I can imagine some people may not see nearly as much wildlife- there is an element of luck involved.

Booked our trip in advance and all went well with meeting the tour guide and the vehicle supplied. Tour was in the afternoon finishing around 6 pm. The disappointment that there was little wildlife to see. Viewed what apparently was a leopard from some 400 metres away.  Saw an elephant in a waterhole.  It is deceptive to arrange tours under such severe drought conditions as there are few animals around. We were informed that the park would be closed in 2 days, but on reading recent reviews this is apparently not the case.  Beware !! make inquiries as to whether weather conditions have improved.

Fantastic place to go on safari. Select the proper season when all the villu's are full of water. Unfortunately we went in the wrong time where most of the villu's were dry. Didn't see much wild life. There is a large area to cover in a good 4 wheel drive vehicle in very good condition. In the thick jungle you can visit the ruins of the Kuveni's palace and the area where King Vijaya landed (Kudiramalai). There are ruins of a monument (very large horse) situated near this place for the sea farerers to see in the olden times. Ideal to spend a day there to enjoy the fauna and flora as well. Take lot of drinking water with you.

We arrived at 7.45 which was probably a bit late but we had a lovely experience. We booked a jeep in advance which saved us Rs 4000 compared to booking when just showing up. Various animals such as birds, monkeys, iguana type things, one elephant and a leopard. We did 3.5 hours which was absolutely fine. Just s lovely relaxing experience in something that does feel like real wildlife.

There are 02 ways which you can visit wilpattu National park :D One is going inside of National park from Hunuwilgama main entrance. The other one is drive on the road going from Mannaram to Colombo through wilpattu national park. Their you just have to drive middle of wilpattu jungle near to 40km. Either way you can find many animals. It will be good to have good ground clearance vehicle for safe side. Specially if you choose second option you have to cross river going across road with shoe bridge. In dried season will have around 1Ft height water which you have to cross and drive through. But rainy time forget to cross here. Having many navy camp inside of this jungle. Be sure to fill gasoline and have spare tire before you start this journey. Be careful with elephant on road when you driving as they are not much familiar with vehicle like in other places. If you choose first option you can do camping in jungle

In the company of a trained naturalist a short morning visit yielded verified sightings of 35 different birds, 15 mammals and 2reptiles. The coast was not visited and thus potential opportunities missed. Elephant , 4different deer(antelope) and crocodile but no leopard. Interest in a wildlife experience must be comprehensive as demonstrated above or why bother going.  Birds have far more to offer than mammals and just need a good pair of binoculars.

We spent an entire day at Wilpattu national park and enjoyed it very much. The driver of our jeep was excellend and we saw a lot of wildlife, such as leopards, sloth bear, elephants, mongoose & many birds. There weren't many jeeps in the park which made the experience even better.

We booked our safari trip 4 days in advance, the price included hotel pick up, 6 hour safari and drop off. We found out that we had to make our own way to the safari as our area wasn't included in the catchment. After arriving and sorting out our jeep, we had to queue at the entrance to the park, at this point we were told our safari would be 3 hours not 6 hours due to 'Government rules ' and the drought. We continued with the safari as our guide didn't understand our complaints with the short notice. We saw no animals at all. We paid the full amount for no animals, half the amount of time and our own pick up and drop off. We would never have paid what we did for 3 hours safari if we had known in advance.

These days due to the severe drought visitors are not allowed to enter the park after 12 noon and only 30 tickets are been issued per day. We asked our safari jeep driver to get there as early as possible and somehow managed to get the tickets. Just 10 mins into the park we came across a huge sloth bear by the road which was busy searching for food (insects) totally ignoring our presence. Amazing ! However, we can clearly see the animals and birds struggling big time due to the drought and most of the waterholes were empty. Kudos to our wildlife department, in the evening huge number of trucks are been sent into the park to fill the waterholes and artificial tanks. Since we were the first to enter the park and one point we saw some leopard footprints on our pathway and our driver started tracking it. However, after following it for about 20 mins it suddenly disappeared. But 15 minutes later our driver got a call from his colleague that they found a leopard, then our driver rushed to the place where there were already four jeeps waiting desperate to get a glimpse of the elusive leopard. A mom and two cubs ! Mom and the elder cub have already crossed the road, the younger one got stuck at the other side as we were blocking the road. The thick dense forest didn't allow us to observe the animal properly. I was able to see only the back and the tail !  Afterwards All four drivers quickly decided to leave and give room for the cub to join her mom. Later on we even came across a dead elephant by the side of the road. Although Wilpattu is the largest national park in Sri lanka it has got the least number of elephants compared to other national parks. Strange isn't it ! This could be the reason for the abundance of bear and leopard population in Wilpattu.

As ever we go game viewing with the expectation of seeing nothing that way we are never disappointed. The landscape reminded me of Hwange- lots of bush with small openings and then bigger vistas around the tanks Great bird life as you would imagine but when you turn a corner at 5 pm and come across a Sloth Bear casually drinking at a watering hole you feel like you hit the jackpot.... then the Leopard stalking wild pig at the next tank followed by watching the sun go down while an old Bull elephant stands in the middle of a lake munching gently away -awesome! Racing back to the park gate before it closed at 630pm we saw another bear - the kids were beaming from ear to ear as we left eagerly awaiting the next morning game drive... couldn't be as good could it.......

We got to the park later than most (around 8:30 am) because we had already done 4 successful safaris during our Sri Lanka trip and didn't feel like getting up early. We still saw many birds, spotted deer, barking deer. But the most interesting was a sloth bear, unafraid and right by the road. We observed him for half an hour, eating and then drinking at the water hole. By the large pond, we saw deer, buffaloes and crocodile. As a cherry on the cake, we saw a leopard in a tree (at a distance).

This park is famous for leopards, elephants, peacocks, jungle fowl etc.  A full day safari jeep cost is Rs. 8,000/-  and one to 6 pax can go. The jeep There is a lot of dust in the park so make sure you cover your camera and face. The safari jeep can organize your breakfast and lunch. The park is open from 6am to 6pm. The only toilet is at the park entrance. You have to be very lucky to spot a leopard because due to the think jungle they are hidden most of the time. The best time to go is in a weekday where there is less vehicles.Make sure you book a single cab pickup and not a Mahindra jeep because this type of jeep is very noisy and scares away the animals.

This nature reserve is famous for Leopards. But remember to book safari vehicles direct rather than trying to book via the hotel etc. One vehicle for Lkr 3500 direct But Lkr4500 as 1000 goes to the intermediary.
Did a morning safari....always a punt with wild animals but saw a bear....elephants...an otter.... elephants an eagle really close up and plenty of birdlife, deeds and gazel.

We went on a full day safari here and were very sad to leave afterwards. We saw so many spotted deer, monkeys and peacocks, several wild boar and crocodiles, a couple of elephants and jackals, and a great variety of birds. Sadly we couldn't see any leopards but it was the most beautiful national park we've been to. We felt like we were in Jungle Book, absolutely mesmerised by the scenery. Visit Yala National Park for leopards, Kaudulla National Park for elephants, and Wilpattu for the scenery and solitude. This was the only safari experience where we were by ourselves in the wild, we only saw five other jeeps at meal breaks but quickly lost them. By the way be careful with monkeys whilst having your food at the breakfast/lunch area, they stole my sandwich!

We visited this park for the day with our driver for the holiday and another driver/spotter.  The drivers, when we meet on the road, exchange information about sightings and of course, we were all after a leopard sighting.  We saw lots of birds, spotted deer, mongoose and had our lunch watching an elephant having his at a watering hole. We did manage to catch a brief glimpse of a leopard, which was bigger than others I'd seen in other places but still a thrill. Despite the heat we were quite comfortable in our vehicle which had a roof for shade but open sides with tiered seats so everyone could see.

Yes we were lucky and we spotted a loepard and were able to watch it for quite a while. But apart from this the jungle itself is very beautiful with lots of wildlife and birds. One of the most beautiful forest area as compared to the southern national parks.

This was the most beautiful forest I saw in Sri Lanka. Other national parks have more small trees and shrubs rather than the the thick jungle experience. Teeming with wildlife and birds. Spotting a leopard is a luck and I was lucky to spot a beautiful leopard.

We have recently been on an afternoon safari to this national park and thought it was great. Be realistic and don't assume that you will see a leopard and you won't be disappointed. We employed the services of a naturalist and yes they do cost you more but as visitors to this lovely land we thought it would be money well spent. The jeep safari was great experience but did not have the luck to see a leopards. but saw lot of animals . Very dry and warm.

If you are there at the right place at the right time, then you see the lot.  In one afternoon safari, we were so fortunate to see leopards, sloth bear, elephants, wild boars, water buffalo's, mongoose, star tortoise, barking and spotted deer and lots of birds,  It was our lucky day, hope they will be still there for our next visit to the park and the Tree House at the Wilpattu Corridor.
Plenty of elephants, a tortoise and even a usually elusive sloth bear. Bird life was varied and interesting. Unfortunately guiding was poor. No leopards.

We were very disappointed with Sri Lanka expeditions safari package as we paid a lot of money for a full day safari but only had a driver who spoke little English. We did not have a guide so drove around all day mostly spotting animals ourselves, and learnt nothing about the park or the wildlife. This tour company is not recommended.

There supposed to be 200 elephants in this park and maybe 25 leopards. Currently the oldest and largest national park in Sri Lanka, Wilpattu is still relatively pristine when compared to more popular parks in Sri Lanka. The Sri Lankan subspecies of the leopard, Panthera Pardus Kotiya, can sometimes be seen here. This park remains a challenge for viewers because animals have plenty of areas where they can avoid being seen - which is exactly the way things should be. I waited 34 years (1981 to 2015) to see my first adult leopard here, but it was well worth the wait. The "Villu" system in this park is also unique. Villus are large ponds - or small lakes, if you prefer - that are surrounded by sand. Most hold fresh water - making them attractive to both predator and prey during times of drought. To enjoy a park like this, be sure to drive slowly. Driving fast can kill the animals that you come to see.

When we were there end of april it was really quite. A extreme long dry period. The bigger animals especially the elephants were aggresive. We didn't see them fortunately. One of the best safari's I have been on and not littering this park will keep it amazing for the animals and for us the visitors.

Our main issue with Sri Lankan tourism is that the prices are continuously changing and getting more and more costly by the day. Here I'll give you a breakdown of what it cost us in Feb 2017. And ill let you know what I thought of it. Here is a breakdown of the costs: Jeep entrance: 250 Jeep hire: 4000rs Park entrance per foreigner: 2175rs Park entrance per local (your driver): 60rs Service charge: 1160 Government tax: 882 Guide: we got this free but often the drivers don't speak English so you'll need a guide as well. Tips: your choice but it's expected that you will. So in total, for 2 people it cost us: 10,762 or about 5000rs each. Basically, whatever a jeep company quotes you, it won't be the full price because there are so many components to the price. As a rough guide, it's always 5000pp for every national park. Obviously the jeep hire is divided by the amount of guests, they are normally 6 seaters. Be prepared, they will be very reluctant to find someone for you to share with because they get less money. Do this without them knowing and pretend you are travelling as a group. The actual park of Wilpattu is nice although the elephant herds are rather small. Also, it's unfair on the animals to chase them around too close so don't expect the up-close encounters. We saw a sloth bear but no leopard. I like Wilpattu more than udawalawe. I haven't been to Yala. Happy safari-ing!!

Wilpattu National Park is situated around 8 km away from the Puttalam - Anuradhapura main road. It is one of the largest National Parks in Sri Lanka which has many "Villu" areas. There are few things which we would like to recommend for anyone who wish to visit this National Park, to take the maximum advantage. It is quite a large national park. When there are lot of safari cabs and vehicles moving, animals get affected by the noise and they will stay inside the jungle. Wilpattu means "10 lakes" in Tamil.  Wil means "lakes" in Sinhalese.  Within this largest national park in Sri Lanka, that is exactly what you will find - Lakes - to which animals come to water - around which they feed - in and around which birds flock!  --- The park was closed during the LTTE war and was re-opened to the public only a few years ago.  It is therefore less visited with not so many jeeps allowing you to savour and enjoy a wonderful true-wilderness feeling. During our visit from 30th January to 1st February 2017, we stayed in one of the bungalows within the park - the Lunuwewa bungalow.  This provides basic accommodation - clean sheets - basic washrooms and toilets.  The visitors need to take dry provisions.  The caretaker and his assistant will cook your meals - Srilankan style.  There were abundant birds in the villu next to where the bungalow is.  We hired two safari jeeps from "Leopard Den" and enjoyed four safari trips.  We were lucky to see both the leopard and the sloth bear during out visit.  We also enjoyed the large bird population as well as spotted and barking deer, sambhur, jackals, buffalo, crocodiles, wild boar and many other species of animals. We enjoyed the serenity of the wild as well as the hospitality of the caretaker of the bungalow, the helpful safari drivers and the guide.  We have booked  to visit the park again on 26th February for 2 nights!! Take a camera with a zoom lens.  You will remember Wilpattu forever!!

Even though we didn't see so many big animals, the scenery is beautiful. One big plus is that there aren't so many cars, hence, the park isn't so crowded and you get to enjoy nature. Summed up: If you like birds and beautiful sceneries then it's the place for you. Of course, you can be lucky and see a leopard and elephants, but don't be disappointed if you don't get to see them.

We went on 3 full day safaris (6-18) in order to see as much as possible. Exotic birds were plentiful e.g. bee-eaters, kingfishers, peacocks, painted storks and various eagles and hawks. We saw several water buffalos, a few wild boars, and some elephants. Generally the elephants can only be seen on a large distance, but one male elephant was looking for water chestnuts in one of the lakes and it was great fun watching him half buried in water. During the 3 days we covered a lot of ground and saw practically every corner of the park. We did appreciate that generally you travel with almost no other jeeps around you. The roads are terrible, so it is really a fun ride and you have to admire the skills of your driver. On the second day, we spotted a young leopard drinking from a small pond no more than 30 m from the road. We got great pictures before he wandered off into the wilderness. This was great luck and generally very few visitors have that luck, so do not expect it to happen. We highly recommend the park, but it is a severe and exhausting effort to drive 12 hours for 3 days in a row. Remember to bring warm clothes, because the mornings can be very chilly.

I visited this nationalpark with my family for two days. First day we went for an exhausting 12 hours, next just a half day trip. Vilpaththu National Park is a newer park in the north west of the island that is growing in popularity.  I chose to come here over Yala and the more famous reserves in the south as I had heard a lot of tales from other travellers about irresponsible operators in that park, harassing the animals and behaving dangerously.  So I decided I'd prefer to visit a park that had lower chances of seeing a leopard, but at least wouldn't put the animal at any risk if I did see one. Vilpaththu does have all sorts of animals living within its forests, including leopards, sloth bears, crocodiles, and a very small number of elephants.  You are not guaranteed to see them.  I have been lucky enough to already see leopards in Africa, so I was perhaps more relaxed about this than some travellers may be. The park consists of dense jungly forest, interspersed with big lakes (the name means 'many lakes').  You drive in high, open sided jeeps along well defined but bumpy red earth tracks, through the forest.  There are relatively few tracks so you tend to take the route there is.  There aren't options for vehicles to go 'off road' due to the forest, which is a good thing as it prevents the environment being degraded. On a four hour trip, I saw lots of different wildlife, including crocodiles (huge, and really good views), spotted and barking deer, mongooses, peacocks, green bee eaters, a serpent eagle, beautiful butterflies, large monitor lizards, two types of monkey, wild boar, and wading birds.  For me, a lot of the joy of a safari is not knowing what you might see next, and its that thrill of the unknown that makes it such a great experience.  Even if you see nothing at all, I find that makes the experience worthy in itself.  Of course, I'm lucky in having done several safaris in different places, so perhaps get less anxious about seeing things that people who might have only had this chance. If I'd had more time, I'd have been happy to stay here and do a few game drives over a couple of days.  I reckon if you went several times you'd have a pretty good chance of seeing a leopard or bear.  You are unlikely to see elephants here, but there are lots of other parks in Sri Lanka where you've got a really high chance, so factor in a trip to one of those too if you can.  It's a well managed park, with no litter and not too many jeeps, and I loved it.  If you have never seen big wildlife before and are desperate to see a leopard, you might be better off going for one of the southern parks.  But I'd highly recommend this park in addition if you can, or for those who are happy to see smaller animals.

The park is half the size of Rhode Island and is full of animal we did not see in Udawalewe or Bundalla. Our kids loved it (aged 7 and 3).
