It's always a question of luck. Many people go to this northern wildlife park to see leopards, which has 38 of them, and never do. We saw 3 in one day, including one that put on a show in the road just a few meters away. Also spectacular is the birdlife; water fowl and eagles. This park straddled the former conflict zone during the civil war and was off-limits for nearly 20 years until the war ended in 2009. It is Sri Lanka's oldest and largest park. Its jungle is dense, making it a challenge to see even large animals. But to me, it is far preferable to Yala National Park in the south, which has so many visitors that its rutted roads are as jammed with traffic as central Colombo. And any leopard sighting attracts an unruly jostling of jeeps. That rarely happens in Wilpattu. The landscape changes dramatically in the northern part of the park, more open grasslands where herds of elephants roam -- though often at a distance. Keep an eye out in the treetops on this side for the magnificent hornbill.

Did a safari for the first time. So we didnt know what to expect. But it was beautifull Saw a lot of animals (crocodiles, Monkeys, Deers, mangoes, a playful baby bear, eagles, a lot of birds and in the end the mother bear). We did a full day and got it for a great price The driver really tried to find the Leopard (we went trough the whole park in area's we didnt saw other jeeps). We were lucky to have a good driver, since there can be a lot of water everywhere and saw other drivers alsmost got stuck. We had so much fun. We went on a busy sunday. but then its only the locals and they dont do a full day. So we were also an unknown species to photograph ;). Thank you Muthalif jeep safari for our great first safari experience. The toilet wasnt so bad. After this we went to Yala also. There we only saw a jungle toilet and the price was twice as high and the park is 20 times as busy. We really perferred Wilpattu more!!

You need to be there before 6am to get tickets. We found this with many Sri Lankan national parks - early opening, but chaos to get the ticket to enter. Once inside - it's a large park with many roads, so you do find yourself alone rather than in a queue of jeeps. Good variety of terrain, ranging from wetlands, jungle and plains. As for wildlife - we didn't see the leopards, bears or elephants but bird life, deers, crocodiles, mongoose, water buffalo, still made it a great day.

When we drove up to the park‚Äôs Hunuvilagama entrance in our rented Fortuner, the ticket man told us none of his ~30 trackers were left (high season!), and therefore he couldn‚Äôt allow us to go in. After some begging, he kindly deputized one of his ~10 park wildlife protection officers (whose shift was about to end) to jump into our car so we could spend 3 hrs going in and out. So for you self-drivers out there, beware of this possibility, since the manager insisted guests were not allowed inside the park without escort. It appears there are no through roads because there‚Äôs only one entrance--so far, although the map we were given at the entrance showed another in the south near Puttalam. Although the 18h30 park closing time is flexible (we left at 18h45 as part of a caravan of 7), park rules forbid artificial light (e.g. headlights!), which (because dark falls quickly at about 18h35) puts a natural limit on your visit. And although that map has far more detail (showing maybe 30 small roads) than Google Maps, still we saw passable tracks not on the map, so a guide would probably know places we can‚Äôt. Jungle fowl, serpent eagle, herons, painted stork, wild boar, spotted and barking deer. The 25kph speed limit isn‚Äôt hard to stick to, given how rutted and bumpy the roads are (if the park has any tarred roads, it‚Äôs not the one at the front gate!).

Wonderful park, 5000 Rs per jeep and then the entrance fee per person. Had a driver and guide (I guess) who both sat in front, so seperated from us and said very little and very often late while we were already taking pictures. Also a long drive (hour or so) to open spots. Here, all is worth it. Big variety and saw many big and small animals. Did a morning tour, left at 5.30 or 6 (too tired, don't remember ;) ) and got back around 11. We saw that day only 15 jeeps or so had signed in at the entrance and it showed; not crowded at all! Nice park away from the crowds and with beautiful variety in animals. Get a better driver/guide than we did though!

The park itself is really lovely although we were very disappointed that we didn't see much fauna. That is of course the luck of the draw and we just hoped, but ce la vie. We took 3 safaris, but failed to see a single Leopard or a Bear. Saw a few deer, one tusker, a few peacocks, Jungle Fowl and their mates, and a crocodile. We also saw wild boar and several birds, and two magnificent Eagles, one a Serpent Eagle. The authorities really need to improve the condition of the tracks. Some of them have very deep gouges and others are completely water logged and impassable. My biggest grouse was the toilets. They are in a shocking condition and a disgrace to the whole country. I shudder to think of what visitors from overseas think of the standard of hygiene of this island. I do believe that the one near the Admin block has not been flushed or cleaned for at least a month. It must have been teeming with Bacteria and a site for air borne diseases. The odours from the one within the park reached at least a 10 meter radius around it. Yuck!!!! The Department of Wildlife Conservation obviously does not care about the awful image created or the health hazards. We fully intend returning when time permits, because although we did not encounter any thrilling experiences, we did prefer it to the other parks in Sri Lanka which are overcrowded with visitors where  one encounters jeeps racing around thoughtlessly. It was much quieter here and to us, a typical wildlife park and not a circus. Since it was a very large park, 13,00 ha, it was not easy to cover much ground with the rough tracks. The Water holes were full since this was post the rains, and were very serene to look at. There were large expanses of water, which could be a reason for the lack of sightings, as the animals probably had small pools inside the jungle to quench their thirst. The park opens at 6 am and closes at 6 pm. One has to allow plenty of time to get to the exit gates in time to be out at 6 pm if you are far away from it.

If you are the out door out going Love to enjoy bumpy sans roads feel the sweat and smell the Green in the air, th√©n Its a wonderful place for family or friend to enjoy with coupled with laughter and satisfaction At the end of the Day. I enjoyed √©very moment and would love to go again.

My love affair with Wilpattu started way back when I was in school. Back then the park was closed for visitors during the war. In 2003, during a ceasefire agreement, we managed to get permission to camp in the park. It was the most exhilarating experience, camping deep in the dense wilderness, next to the clear waters of the Moderagam Aru. Due to heavy poaching back then the sightings were few, but I will never forget the massive tusker I encountered on Percy Bendhi wewa close to the park entrance. I named the tusker "Wasantha" after the gutsy park warden back then Mr. Wasantha Pushpananda. Since then I cant count how many time I have visited the park. Maybe over 500 times. As a review what I would say is this park gives the most complete and "real" wildlife and wilderness experience out of all the parks in Sri Lanka. Don't come expecting a quick fix of wildlife, where a one day trip would result in a loads of wildlife. Remember this is not a zoo ! this is a real national park with real wild animals and they would choose to appear or disappear. I would highly recommend spending at least 2 full day safari's in the park to get a real feel of the place. Also having a great driver/guide is a must. This is the place, where if I die, I want my ashes scattered, its that special to me. Over the last 13 years of visiting the park, I have seen many amazing sighting, from 5 hour leopard sightings, to tuskers, bears, elusive and rare Forest Eagle Owls, our jeep being rammed by a wild boar and so much more. This is THE park to visit when your visiting Sri Lanka.

We took a Safari to Wilpattu National Park and thoroughly enjoyed the experience - we saw monkeys, jackals, spotted deer, muntjac deer, wild boar and mongeese - but the number of wild mammal sightings may not be enough to interest all. We also enjoyed seeing large numbers of birds. We suspect that most people would want to have two interests eg mammals/birds or mammals/flora to keep them fully engaged.

This was my first visit Wilpattu. I was appalled by the state of the toilets near the ticket counter and also inside the park.  Almost all the comments on the Guest Book refers to the poor state of the toilets. It appears that the Department of Wildlife Conservation in Sri Lanka have turned a deaf ear to the requests to keep the toilets clean or build a new set of toilets suitable for foreigners to use. The overall experience in the park was very good. We were at the park in late December which is also the tail end of the monsoon season. The park was lush and green and most of the ‚ÄúVillu‚Äôs‚Äù or Lakes were at full capacity. The park name ‚ÄúWilpattu‚Äù is derived from these shallow ‚ÄúVillu‚Äôs‚Äù. Driving on the water filled sand banks of the ‚ÄúVillu‚Äôs were a great experience The sanctuary is located in the dry part of the country and it is the dryness of the surrounding that attracts animals to the many waterholes.  We didn‚Äôt get to see too many animals because there is plenty of water inside the jungle for them to drink. We were lucky to spot a bear as we were leaving the park. The park is very large (appox 13,00 ha) and was declared a wild life sanctuary in 1938. We arrived at the park around 2.00 pm and were forced to leave before the gates close at 6.00 pm. Allow plenty of time if visiting this park. It located approximately 188 Km‚Äôs from Colombo and will take about 4 hours to get there from Colombo.  Tickets have to be bought at the entrance and hiring a four wheel drive is highly recommended. The park is open from 6 am to 6 pm. The best time to visit the park is between 6 -10am or 3 ‚Äì 6 pm in the evening. The entrance to the park is from Nochchiyagama and can be reached from Puttalam to Anuradhapura road. The animals we saw included peacocks, flamingo‚Äôs, serpent eagles, Ceylon jungle fowl, Green bee eater and many other species of birds. Also we saw, water buffalo, wild boar, deer, bear, rabbits and many crocodiles. The best time to visit the park is between February to October.

We visited the safari with family in Dec 2015. However, we were not satisfied with the experience because of following reasons: 1. Park/Jungle is huge and very dense. May be because we visited in Dec which is rainy season in SL, the thick vegetation on sides of the road impacted the views 2. Animal sighting was poor. We understand it is not Zoo but after paying Foreign Toursit Fees with small kids we felt it was not worth the money and time spent. The kids were bored within half an hour into the ride. 3. Requested for Forest Ranger or Guide at entrance. However it was not available (Not Sure if the facility is not available or person was not available). That left us to interact with Driver of Safari vehicle who obviously was tasked to drive the safari vehicle safely rather than interact with tourists.

We had great luck and saw a leopard sitting on a tree and afterwards walk closely to the jeep. We had a lot of rain in the last days, so the ponds were filled up with water and no animals were there. We saw a crocodile, deers, birds, leguans, etc. - but no bears, elephants. With the leopard a clear five star, without only two stars.

We visited the safari with Family and it was not a great experience. We do understand that it is not zoo with certainty of animal sightings but the after paying the hefty tourist fee of foreigners it was not worth the time and money spend. In the whole tour we saw very few animals

We saw lots of wildlife on our safari through wilpattu: Sambar, spotted and barking deer, crocodiles, wild boars, Mongoose, monkeys, jackels, monitors, peacocks, hawk-eagle and many other birds! We did not see a leopard (only tracks!), but a few other people did see one that day :) great to know they're still around! We booked a driver through eagle safaris, which they never confirmed so it was a bit of a hassle to sort out when we arrived, but it worked out ok. Our driver did not speak any English, but was good at spotting things and it was fine as we know quite a bit about wildlife, but might have been difficult if we didn't know which species we would see. Amazing park for those who are keen to see Sri Lankan animals in their natural habitat without loads of tourists! Highly recommended!

As you probably read in any Sri Lanka travel guide this national park reopened only in 2009. It's Sri Lanka's biggest park, but in terms of wild life it's thinly spread. Our tour was however still amazing, the park is beautiful, but we didn't see what we come for... Not the park's fault of course. The number of visitors in the park is very low which is of course a big plus. We had a private jeep with a great driver and spotter. He was very knowledgeable about the park and all the (wild) life inside. The park is well laid out. I had a bit of a feeling too much was 'touched'. Maybe in a couple of years this is the best place to go again...

This place is awesome. It's wild and 'mostly' free of tourists. During our whole day safari we only encountered two other jeeps. We had a terrible driver but being in a group of 4 wildlife biologists we were able to spot loads of wildlife including 30min with an elephant playing in the water and not a single human soul to be seen. Bliss! It definitively gets hots and you might not see lots for some period of time but this is the essence of wildlife encounters. All the people complaning about not seeing a leopard or about the lack of widlife do not understand the concet of a wild animals and must have a poor understanding of nature based tourism. It is not a Zoo and you might not see things, this is part of the game! If all you care about is a selfie with a Leopard than this place is not for you. If you ar enot ready to divert from wildlife and enjoy the scenery and natural aspect of i all, again, this place is not for you. Try and avoid the rainy season November-December as you might not get to see the whole park due to the roads being flooded. I loved it and will be back for sure.

we got a safari jeep for 4500/= for half day tour. park entry ticket price was 405 per person.went on the "Panikka wila" route. don't go in November- end and December, as its the rainy season. The probability to saw a bear is around 5-6.

It is a nice park. Less visited by tourist which is good because you dont see a lot of jeeps in front of you. You feel almost alone in the park. The only thing is that you need to rent a Jeep (4,500 rupies for 4 hours If I am not mistaken) plus the park entrance fee. We saw quite a few animals, but it all depends on your luck and whether it is the dry or raining season.

Well known for its leopards - but it is hit and miss if you want to see a leopard for certain go to the zoo - but you will see lots of birds, many predatory types feature along with fishing birds and parrots.  Croodiles seem to be freequently sighted from babies on small ponds to larger ones sunning themselves by their established homes at various waterholes.  Plenty of Water Buffalo and some elephants though we only saw one at dusk.

The ride to 'Wilpattu National Park' took some hours. Once arrived, there was time for a bathroom break. After which we went into the park with our driver. We drove for many hours through the park on bad roads full with holes (in all sizes). This was a bit of an unpleasant ride because after some time you get enough of the shaking in the back of a truck. The guide sitting next to the driver pointed out various animals we saw / encountered. But that is all the two of them did. Drive and point. There were no other interactions, no additional information or anything. Unfortunately, this might have had more to do with the trip we booked then with the park itself. We booked a trip at a place across our hotel to the 'Wilpattu National Park'. I‚Äôve been in South Africa before and did some safaris through several parks. Compared to them, Wilpattu seems like childsplay. But maybe mid November is not the best time? We saw quite some things; I‚Äôll list them in order of interest: -- A cute small/medium sized bear was hiding in the bushes. Took some time for him to come out and he crossed the road. -- Just before we left the park, we saw an elephant hidden behind bushes. -- A cool green/blue bird. -- Some deers. -- Some monkeys. -- A lizard or two. -- Two white storks. -- Quite some peafowl.

Lovely day out, we went during the dry season so were NEVER going to see leopards and Bears, but were treated to Monkeys, Grizzly Squirrels, Eagles aplenty, Eagle Owl, deer, baby crocodiles, water buffalo, wild dogs, mongoose, monitor lizards, peacocks and many beautiful birds and butterflies.

We took our kids (14 and 11) on the half day safari from 6am to 11am, while staying in Anuradhapura. The park was uncrowded and we enjoyed some serene moments when the driver turned off the engine for us to enjoy the wildlife. In addition to the plentiful peacocks, deer and land monitors we spotted wild boar, eagles, hornbills, storks, crocodiles, mongooses, a colony of bats and an elephant. I think our children were old enough to appreciate the trip, but for younger children the wildlife is probably too hidden and the ride is very bumpy. Binoculars were great for getting a bit closer to the action. Our driver was a great spotter, but with hindsight I would have liked to have had a guide to get more background information about what we were seeing. We had a fun trip. We didn't visit any other parks in Sri Lanka, so I guess you would need to read other reviews to find out if another park is more suitable depending on what you're looking for.

Peaceful and unforgettable.  To say it was once an area ravaged by war, I have to say it has survived and is steadily evolving and life is returning.  If you are looking for a touristy park with lots of wildlife, this is not for you, go to Yala for that.  If you hope to see wildlife but are not really worried if you don't, then this is for you.  I only hope that the government have the sense to restrict numbers entering the park as it is best that the wildlife is left peacefully to recover.  Absolutely loved it and the views are stunning and our indebted thanks to Leopard Trails and Indika and his team who made it absolutely memorable.

Hence my Kids wanted to have  a wild safari & the famous Yala National Park closed for one month,we decided to visit Wilpattu National Park. Our safari tour organized from the place we stayed.They have their own safari Jeeps with professional drivers.We started our tour around 1.30pm .We have taken  half a day package.Before entering to the Wilpattu National Park we must take tickets to enter by registering the details of passengers ,driver,vehicle at the office near the main entrance.Its not just taking tickets but also for the safety of all visitors . When we just entered we founded a notice that we should not throw anything. First we heard many noises from many kind of birds,beetles.Saw plenty of Peacocks ,Bulls.When we went more inside to wilpattu we founded lots of Deers & founded uncommon Deer called  " Sand Deer ".It was inside the bushes and very difficulty to identify because of its color same as the sand of the area.Because of our Drivers professionalism we were able to seen an Elephant which others have not seen it until we have informed where they can see.Wild animals were less to see because many animals has been switched to very far areas in the park where you needed a full day tour to see them.We started to return around 5.15pm & on  the  way back we founded a black color Bear. We have reported to the main entrance checked point around 6.30pm & safely reached our hotel . It was a unforgettable wild safari.Thanks to our Driver.

Our guide suggested to visit Wilpattu NP instead of Yala NP, because Yala would be closed when we supposted togo there for a safari. This was a perfect alternative! Unfortinately we didn't saw a leopard during but it didn't made our experience less wonderfull. During our afternoon safari (app. 4h), we saw some elephants, deers, lizards, crocodiles and a lot of birds. We heard many stories about Yala is being popular and more crowded than Wilpattu. In the time we were on safari, we didn't saw another jeep. You can enjoy the beautifull nature, silence and animals in the wilderness!

It was a really good day. We're in raining seasons , an we can see and leopard and elephants . Thanks to de driver . He didn't stop until find de Leopard. :) . Amazing day. Thanks Muthalif jeep safari

We spend the afternoon searching for leopard, but unfortunately we couldn't find any. Concerning other breeds you can see the same animals outside the park so no need to spend 3 to 4 hrs of your life at Wilpattu National Park.

We went on safari from the Big Game Camp Wilpattu - the vehicle was very comfortable and the scenery is interesting - heaps of raptors and hornbills, plus elephant. There are also landrovers at the junction - it looked very easy to go on safari even if you hadn't booked ahead.

We went to Wilpattu instead of Yala for a chance to see a leopard in the wild. I had to change my group's itinerary at the last minute due to the announcement of Yala that it will be closing on the day my group was supposed to go there for a safari. I think it was the best unfortunate circumstance to happen because we managed to spot leopards on 3 different areas of Wilpattu. The park is beautiful. We went in early September so it was the end of the drought season. Near the opening of the park, it was dry and almost arid but deeper into it you will see the lush fullness of the forest around the reservoirs. Our guide, Krishan Fernando of Triplanka Tours was a god send. If you're a bird watcher you will love the guy. He identified all the wildlife we saw, most especially the birds. He knows all the local birds of Sri Lanka by heart. He even brought binoculars with him. Had a good eye in spotting the wildlife in the bushes, better even that our hired park driver. We paid 3300rupees each for a group of 6 people for 6 hours in the afternoon in the park. Thats 130-630pm. We opted afternoon with the thought that the animals will start appearing after the heat of midday, maybe near the watering holes. We were lucky. We saw a 2 year old adult male leopard 3-4 hours into the safari. It was just right there. Lounging beside a bush at the edge of clearing near a lake. Like a boss. The other two we saw while going back to the entrance. Along the road! One was around an 18 month old female who probably just left the care of its mum as our guides said and another was a cub, barely a year old. so the mum was also probably hiding somewhere in the bush. We didn't spot a sloth bear, our guide said it wasn't the time of the year but the leopards alone were so worth it. Just hope for the best though, not everyone sees one. They do get scared if there are too many jeeps around. We were lucky there were only a max of maybe 15 jeeps that afternoon with us. A couple we talked to spent an entire day at the park without seeing a single leopard or bear. Just birds.

We took a half day tour in the evening and we saw few deers, two elephats, some peacocks, a group of buffolos and hundred of tousands of butterflies... sadly no leapords for us Please prepare some snacks for yourself and the deivers too as been informed by our guesthouse.

My views regarding Wilpatthu being the National Park of choice for a visitor who values peace and solitude over pure check marking animal sightings remains valid, Yala offers a much more concentrated wild life experience with a higher probability of animal and bird sightings, and Uda walawe and in Season Minneriya and Kaudulla are hard to beat for elephant lovers. Wilpatthu , however remains in my eyes at least, heaven on earth for anyone seeking to reconnect with nature and who values the feeling of being in the wilderness It is much less popular than Yala, and I wish , very selfishly I may add, that it remains so, so we will be spared the excesses of human nature that Yala so unfortunately exemplifies. The reason for this mini review is purely to highlight the extreme levels of rainfall this park has received and is due to receive in about a month or two. Several popular tracks are impassable. Please check with your tour operator or guide before you venture into the park thee days, and be very sure of the capability of both your vehicle and driver to manage wet conditions

We were lucky to have a good cab driver with excellent animal tracking ability. We left the gate at about 8 am. We spent about 10 hours in the jungle and we could see more than 40 types of animals including elephants, dears, monitors, fox, peacocks, jungle fowls and various types of birds. The cab driver pointed out various types of birds which was great help as we were unfamiliar .

We visited Wilpattu in August this year and drove around for 3 1/2 hours but unfortunately we didn't see anything other than lizards and monkeys that you can see anywhere in Sri Lanka. We were hoping to see sloth bears, elephants and or leopards, sadly none of them were in town the day we went.

A great National park with an abundance of Bird/wildlife but without the huge numbers of tourists of other parks such as Yala. Saw the majority of large mammals we were after including Leopard but unfortunately no Sloth Bear. Saw over 40 different Species of Bird including Lesser Adjutant.

Try and book a jeep before going there. And a tracker. If you are an expat... expect to pay a premium to get in. If you want to see animals go in after noon. Around 4 or 5pm they come out from the heat to drink water etc. "The palace of Kuweini" is a LONG 'time' away. Around 4 hours of driving from main gate. (And you have to come back). Lots of beautiful scenes though. Go for the half day trip. Cheaper and kinder on the body as the safari jeeps are not meant to be comfortable. Eating too much food is not advisable.  Nor is drinking too much water unless you can hold your bladder for hours while your body is bouncing up and down; as you are not allowed to stop for pit stops except at designated areas. .. which are far and few in between.

Unlike some other reviewers, I wasn't lucky. In the whole day, I saw lots of birds, a few deer, and one elephant. However, the marshland scenery is beautiful, but after several hours it gets old, as it's the same. At the breakfast and lunch stop, take the short walk to the lake--about 100 meters. It's relaxing and peaceful there, and there are the most interesting frogs to watch.

We booked a safari to Wilpattu national park from Anuradhapura. The trip started in the morning at 5:15h from our hotel. The car was nice and brought us directly to the park. Hopefully we bought some breakfast before, since there was no possibility to get some (the hotel, hievet, offered to prepare us breakfast for some phantasy price extra, which we did not do). The six hour half day trip was unfortunately very very boring. We saw dogs, chicken, several birds, frogs and as a tiny highlight two crocodiles. That was it. No elephants nor any other interesting animals. In total very disappointing, definitely not worth the 7000RS we paid per person.

We stayed near the entrance which was great for watching birds and the locals bathing in the river. Our driver tried hard to spot the wildlife, it would have been a little better if he spoke a little English, but nevertheless it was a great day.  We spotted a Leopard,crocodiles,eagles,deer, wild boar and lots of birds. Take food and water with you as nothing in park. We did all day trip very bumpy and lasted 12.5 hours.Shame about rubbish around "toilet ". Hardly any western tourists but quite a few locals as it was a long weekend.  Exhausting day but well worth it as we spotted the leopard in the middle of the day.

It is a vast land with a lot of lakes and swamp areas. We went early in the morning. Our driver was great, he spoted a lot if animals for us. We were unlucky since there were no elephants, but we saw a leopard, crocodiles, monkeys, birds and all kind of deers... Worth to go, but for at least a half day tour

We had two early morning trips to Wilpattu in July 2015. There were no more the five jeeps in the whole park. We were lucky enough to see a huge variety of wildlife including four leopard. Seeing the leopard is by no means guaranteed but this park is quietly understated and is an enjoyable morning out.

It is a life time experience if you could spot a fully grown leopardin Wilpattu. Make sure you get in to the park before first light suppose you can't be at the gate by six better visit the park in the afternoon. Many people go on half a day safari but my advice is be prepare to stay in the park from morning to evening then you have a good chance to see some animals and may be to go to Foul point and Thambapanni as well.

The park was nice even of we see no elephant and leopard, but the jeep driver was seraching. Anyway we had a very bad experience with the Park View Bungalow. The place looks nice expect the fact there is absolutly no food. The owner send you at the junction to buy food at tourist price for dinner... Obviously it takes one hour to go and bring food and transportation cost is at your own expenses. We ask to have food at the kitchen, bu the owner did not want to understand, and for breakfast which was supposed to be included after complains, we get a cup of tea (no bread or fruit). When we say we did not want to pay the full price... the owner says he will call the police and call my wife bitchy. Lovely place... Then to visit the willpattu park it is better to stay close to the junction or to bring all your stuff.

Wilpattu National Park is such a great & clam place to watch animals. This park is full of elephants, monkeys, deer,Wild Boar, Birds, Sri Lankan Bear, Crocodiles and many more. and I was lucky enough to spot a leopard as well

We really enjoyed our three days in the park. We had chosen Wilpattu for the opportunity to see Sloth Bear and we were not let down. We were lucky to find one near the road in an open area and we watched it for 20 minutes. There were other vehicles in the park but was nowhere near as busy as Yala which made it very enjoyable.

We did a morning drive at Wilpattu. It was very good ... Elephants, crocodiles, monkeys, deer, wild boars, monitor lizards, and lots of birds. Other people on the same day saw a leopard in the afternoon. It was quite difficult to get a driver with a jeep but we got one in the end.

Unfortunately I can't say anything else than disappointed. I am a diver a certainly know that the wild isn't a zoo. The drive in to see the animals was super long, specially when traveling with small kids. We saw 2 elephants, a group of deers, water buffalo and some birds. Others in the camp where we stayed did a whole day safari and they saw the leopards, crocodiles etc. I think the driver / the guide makes a lot of difference. When we asked if leopards were around, the guide just said the season isn't right, but i think he couldn't have cared less... The nature, with the big lakes is beautiful though, other parts just look like a European forest! I wouldn't recommend it for small kids for sure. Whole day safari probably, as you cover so much more of the park. The entrance the park was 4700LKR for 2 adults (if I remember right). We have done the elephant safari of Minneriya, much more touristic, but we saw 70-80 elephants. July is a good month there apparently, because it's very dry, so the elephants gather at the reservoir for their end of day bath and sunset drinks.

I have been to other wildlife safaris and this one was the most boring of all. We even slept half of the time due to boredom of not finding anything new and interesting on the way. Only found a few birds, peacocks, deers and one baby crocodile (which I could have found in my country also).

It takes a bit of patience, but you can spot a lot of amazing animals while out on Safari.  The scenery around the lakes is breathtaking while you are likely to see elephants roaming freely and the occasional leopard if you spend a few days.

I hesitated to write this review because I'm well aware that wildlife isn't a zoo, ready to be experienced comfortably whenever you decide show up. Who knows, a day earlier or later, and our trip might have been very different..? Bearing that in mind I still decided to report here how disappointing our trip was today. After all, I'm not particularly spoiled when it comes to Safaris, never having been to Africa for example. We made a similar trip a few years ago in Perus jungle region near Puerto Maldonado, and we haven't seen anything larger than a Capybara. Still, there there was a general feeling of the forests around us teeming with wildlife, with animal noises abound and much rustling and cracking in the underbrush... In comparison, Wilpattu felt about as exotic and alife as your standard European mixed forest. Some birds, some lizard, a few deer... That was it. Not for a minute was I under the impression that it would've been risky to leave the Jeep and have a stroll around. Some guides did even that. Of course, there must've been a small chance to run into a Leopard, but the chances of that happening seemed slimmer than being bit by a venomous snake somewhere else in the country. We've seen more animals on a two hour bike trip in Anuradaphura than in these five mildly boring hours on the backseat of the Jeep in Wilpattu. And the bike tour certainly didn't cost us $120. Even worse, the road into the park was the same as the road back, so after 2 1/2 hours even the scenery started to repeat... If you consider doing this trip while in Anuradaphura: - Consider another park maybe, if your travel plans allow for it..? E.g. the Eco park near Sigirya was a slight disappointment for the couple accompanying us, but in there at least we saw a bunch of Elephants a Tortoise and many of the same birds in half the time at a fraction of the cost. Later they showed us amazing pictures of their trip to Yala (which by itself seems to be dismissed by many experienced travelers as not being a must-see). If you're anywhere near those places, and if you don't get a much better deal for Wilpattu than we did, these might give you better value for your money and time. - If there's just two of you, try to find some other travelers to share the cost of the Jeep... Nothing will soften the blow for the entrance fees which are as steep as everywhere else in Sri Lanka. - Make sure you book a GUIDE, not just a DRIVER. I knew beforehand that this would have been preferrable but I was too lazy to look further for better options. Our driver missed more animals that we spotted (scaring them away with the Jeep) than the other way around, and we felt that he already wanted to have it over with way before we left the park. All in all, a big disappointment for us.

Entrance fee (rs 7800/ 3 adults) and we found a jeep charging rs 5000. No tracker was available but for me this just added the fun as now I get to play tracker. But our jeep driver was very good, he found crocodiles elephants spotted deer mongoose monkeys( 2 types) rabbits peacocks eagles lizards Buffaloes and many birds. Unfortunately no leopards or bears. But we did see leopard's foot prints. Was a beautiful tour non the less. Total tour took 4.5 hours. We left at 7.30am. Only one toilet half way through but it was in an AWEFUL condition. There were a few concrete cylinders lying around which altered the wildlife feel the place had going. Bring lunch and water as there are no shops inside at all. Every payment must be done in Sri Lankan rupees , USD not accepted here. So ensure you have enough money on you ( same goes for all the national parks in Sri Lanka ) Tip bring a can or two of beer on board the jeep while driving around ( if you want to). But please do NOT litter. No dustbins in the jungle so please keep all the rubbish on board the jeep and throw it at the end of the tour.

Wilpattu park was a very good experience. I loved the smell of the forest, and the constant noises of birds and insects. We've managed to see the bears, crocodiles, an elephant, several mangosteens, lots and lots of deers, and many different birds. We didn't find a leopard, but we've seen traces of one. At the same time the place looked quite artificial to me. One can see concrete pipes and rubber hoses in many places. And the animals seemed to be at exactly those places where the driver expected to find them.

Wilpattu National Park is the largest in Sri Lanka, located on the north-western coast of the island. The park's unique feature are the large lakes that attract much bird life. It is home to leopard, bear, sambar, elephant, deer, crocs, peacock, jungle fowl to name a few. A visit to the park requires a minimum of half a day, however a full day visit (6am- 6pm) is highly recommended since the attractions to be visited are located at least 40 - 50 km from the park entrance and hence cannot be visited within half a day. The scenery is beautiful and relaxing, if you are lucky you may be able to have a river bath in one of the limited locations visitors are permitted to alight. (Kokmote camp site) You can hire a safari jeep at the entrance, the ride can be quite bumpy due to the terrain. There are no places to buy food, so be prepared with packed breakfast, lunch, snacks and lots of drinking water.

On our first visit to Sri Lanka we went to Yala Park like all other tourists. We liked that experience so this time - on our 2 nd visit - we planned on visiting 2 other parks. We had a good 4X4 jeep and a experienced driver. It took some time before we actually spoted anything. But thin it was cresendo all the way: peacocks, deer, birds... and yes: a leopard and Aisan bear. So this was just perfect. It's wildlife so I guess you need to be lucky. The wild animals don't just sit and wait to show themselves off. So, it can be a dissapointing experience too. But not in our case. The early drive (5:30 a.m.) was worth it!

We went to visit the park. After driving 2.5 to get there, we spent another 4 hours being bounced like yoyos in the back of an open aired jeep. So we saw some dear, bulls, peacocks. We saw 2 elephants miles away you'd need a telescope from Nasa to see. No leopards or bears. By the end we were so tired we just coun't wait to see the end of it. Finally the toilets were filthy and could not be used Its very expensive to get in. $30 per adult which in my mind is not worth it. Having said that i consider it to be a contribution ot the upkeep of the grounds

Peaceful place to watching Wild animals and amazing trip to Thambapani. Very experience cab drivers and you can enjoy maximum in the journey. Watching Wild Elephant's, Leopards, Wild Boar, Birds, Sri Lankan Bear, Crocodiles and many more animals. One advice to you all. You should be there before 6 o'clock in the morning. Feel it and Love it. Keep only your Foot prints. Well recommend place to every one.

I visited park in a evening around 6pm and I saw a large leopard which is a very very rare sight by a visitor and so many peacocks (in Jumbo size )  , Wild Boars , Deer  and samburs (Stags) . The park is very much different than the other parks I visited and full of ponds, lakes and marshy lands. Various kind of birds a a common sight and ponds are full of lotus and other water flowers. Very nice scenarios with the sunset and within 2 hours I reach to the other end of the Park.( Start from Puttlam end and reach to Elluwankulam end.) Due to the darkness came out early and advised to reach the park much as early. No communication mean / no mobile coverage in the park and advise to use a 4 wheel drive vehicle. Carry some water bottles ,caps and shades coz the climate is hot. Do not carry any plastic/ polythene coz its plastic free /restricted zone and pls carry everything back what you carry in. Park is very secured place to visit and you can relay enjoy the one of the best gifts by the mother nature.

This is a park for those who want to experience a bit of wildlife and a taste of Sri Lankan nature. But don't have too high expectations, a safari tour in the park is not to be compared with the ones in southern Africa. You will see some different species of birds, lizards, water buffalo, spotted dear, barking dear, Asian elephants, wild pig and hundreds of butterflies. We were lucky to see one of the parks biggest draws up close - the Slot bear. You can either choose a morning drive or an evening drive. The morning drives are probably better than the evening ones. Most important though is to get a proper ranger, and not only a driver of a safari jeep. It can make a huge different to have someone that point out the animals and name them. We got unfortunately the other kind, a driver. The price of a 4 hour tour is on the high side. Make sure to bring water/snacks before you enter the park.

Wilpattu is a fantastic national park.  We spent three days there staying in the Eco Team tented camp.  We had two very close encounters with leopards and saw others at a distance. We also saw a jackal dive into a thicket to pick up its baby in its mouth and run off at speed to a safer place - there was a leopard in the thicket!  Our guide - Dhanu - was extremely knowledgeable and the range of wildlife from the tiniest birds to huge elephants was amazing.  A visit which will be remembered for ever.
A top place for wildlife lovers. We visited over 3 days and saw leopards,sloth bear,jackal, lots of elephants, deer, crocodiles and mongooses, etc, and we logged over 70 different birds.

Went on an early am safari - this park is enormous, and just now beginning to come back after the civil war ended in 2009.  I didn't see any animals other than a couple water buffalo and some deer.  I think both the size of the park and the decline in animals over the years makes it very difficult to really spot any abundance.  However, the park itself looks like it is well maintained and the Sri Lankans are trying to promote awareness of the need for animal habitat.

Famous for leopards, elephants, many bird species.......bungalows inside the park are in great demand. Guest houses around the turn off to the park......comfortable, Airconditioned......Teal cottage best....Leopards den ok.....the guest house will arrange a jeep......ask for Bobby or Wimalasena.....enter early...6AM.....take your breakfast in the park....the guest house will pack a breakfast for you. Return to guest house for lunch and a rest......get back to the park at 3pm. On lucky days you will see many leopards. I was not lucky......this time. My friends have seen plenty in one day!

Visited the park in March which is the end of the rainy season, therefore the lakes were very full (we were actually driving through the edges of them). Believe this is why we didn't see any elephants as the animals don't move about much when there's plenty of water about. Despite this we saw a lot of deer, lizards, couple of jackals, peacocks and other birds. The vegetation itself was also very scenic. We didn't have a guide but don't think this would have helped in our situation. The drivers all stop when they pass each other to find out if anyone has spotted wildlife.

Ok, it rained, and as we passed through the entrance it poured and then flooded (rare for February), but this national park was a waste of time. It took forever to get there from the airport along the coast road North which is an endless sprawl of shabby ribbon development, and not the best introduction to Sri Lanka. After three and a half hours of a stomach-churning jolt from one pothole to another along an enclosed narrow sandy track, made worse by the jeep convoys which are obligatory, we saw a rabbit, a tortoise, a chicken, a log (which might have been a crocodile) and the backside of a water buffalo, not animals exactly known for their wild ways.Give it a miss: you'll see more wildlife in Kandy's excellent Botanical Gardens.

When we stayed for 3 nights at Nilketha Hotel, Anuradhapura, Adrian, the manager, booked a full-day safari for us at Wilpattu National Park.  Our driver was so brilliant, making sure we didn't miss a thing - and we saw some amazing wildlife and had every opportunity to take great shots of the things we saw. And oh!  What we saw!! An elephant taking a bath in the marshes; several kingfishers and bee-eaters posing for photos on tree-branches; peacocks galore on the trails and in the bushes; an eagle glaring at us from the tree-tops with beady, hypnotic eyes; spotted deer in herds grazing in the bush - mums and dads and babies.  And then we came across a leopard, sauntering through a clearing in the jungle, looking so gorgeous.  It was so other-worldly somehow - and I still can't quite believe our luck.  Our driver was really on the ball, getting us as near as possible to this beautiful creature.  I'm sure if I'd leaned out a little more from the 4WD I'd have been able to touch him.  My husband and I were so fortunate to have the driver and the 4WD to ourselves - especially since we passed a lot of tourists packed to the hilt in their vehicles.  We felt privileged and downright spoiled!  What a wonderful day - warm and breezy - lots to see - lots of breaks to eat our packed lunches and head to the loo. WOW!

One hour drive from Anuraadhapura. Our hired 4W was waiting at the entrance. I truly ask them to pick us up from our Anuraadhapura hotel but then the charges will be double. So drop the idea. Great place to visit. With good guide you will be seen a World which was just hidden from naked eye. Good Camera with Zoom lences are must. We had BF in the jungle. Oh God monkeis are the problem. As you are going to stay in the jungle for around 4 hours (Hald day Safari) it is advisable to use washrooms before enter. Leoperds den is a good tourist hotel with good food. You can visit them at the main road turn to National park.

I felt like Vilpaththu struck a good balance between reasonable regulation and flexible freedom. Our hostel arranged a driver who took us to the park and then transferred us to a park jeep in which we spent the morning hunting around for leopards. Spoiler Alert: We found two jaguars and they were magnificent to see up close. Neither they nor the peacocks, deer or other animals were particularly skittish so it made for great photos. We observed both park department jeeps as well as private vehicles but all the drivers seemed to be in touch so that when a sighting was made, the other vehicles were able to coordinate to maximize sightings. We were able to get out and stretch at a designated rest zone (with a bathroom). I wished that we had more time to spend there and we appreciated that the guides were both expeditious in their attempts to cover as much ground as possible but also stayed put as long as we felt like taking pictures at a given spot. Good times.

Wilpattu National Park is the largest national park in Sri Lanka. It's is much advisable to spend at least two days to enjoy the stay if you want to take loads of pictures. And also bring a good zoom lens :) . You have to have patience in order to see lots of animals. Start as early as possible. The park opens to the public at 6.00 am.  And closes at 6.00 pm. You can reserve a safari Jeep prior visiting the park to avoid any discomforts. Bring your own food since you can't find any outlet once you start the journey. And please bring only the memories and photos. The animals are bit tough to see if you travel during the monsoon rain season, because they are plenty of water holes and they don't travel much in order to quench their thirst. So travelling during the dry season will worthy of your visit.

Did two trips into the park on successive days. As other reviews have said, there are few roads and the jungle is fairly dense. You have to work hard to find and see animals and birds and its not easy to get good photos. Few other tourists. We have visited Yala three times where its an easy tourist trip but we did enjoy Wilpattu.

Though you have to get up early, it's worth it when you get to see so many different animals living in the wild plus so many different landscapes. A half-day safari is plenty though: the park is enormous and you will see a huge amount of things within 4 hours.

The park is great, but there are 26km from the entrance until you get to the main area where most of the animals can be found and beautiful watering holes.  You see some in those 26km, but it normally is kind of empty and you lose some time just going in and out.

Some visitors give the park 1 star, other give the park 5 stars. How is that possible? We went to Wasgomuwa NP Udawawele NP, Yala NP and Wilpattu NP and can compare these parks. We put Wilpattu on the top position with 5* mainy because there are hardly any other tourists, the park is very big, the trackers love their park √°nd they have all the wildlife! We spent the wole day in the park (from 6 am to 6 pm) and were never bored! We don't think you must give 1* or 5* because you see a lot of wildlife or you didn't see any wildlife. On our day In Yala nobody saw a leopard and the day before us 4 leopards were spotted. Spotting the wildlife is not a reason for us to give 1* or 5* because th WILDlife is unpreditable. We give Wilpattu 5* because the park really gives you the feeling of being in a wild national park. It's huge, there are many different habitats and people at the ticket office, the locals, the driver and our tracker all love the park and love to welcome tourist after 25 years of war. In Yala, it's too touristic, they just want your money... Spotting a leopard in the wet season in Wilpattu is difficult and we were lucky to be the only ca (out of the 10 in the park) that day to spot a leopard. In the dry season they spot as many as 10 leopards on 1 day. Wilpattu has a lot of elephants, 3 species of deer, crocodiles, big lizards, turtles, lots of birds etc. So the park has a friendly and relaxed atmosphere and that is something Yala doesn't have at all. So, go to Wilpattu and you wil NOT be disappointed

We left Kalpitya for a day trip (started visit at 2pm, ended visit by 6:30pm) and diversify our activities from beach and kitesurfing The park is stunning and the jeep was old-school as we love it! Driver was really knowledgeable and had the eyes to spot living creatures from small birds to a big male elephant, including a variety of deers, crocodiles... but no leopard, who apparently do not like rain and wet grounds One CAVEAT, lodges around are really pricey and given the lack of competition do not offer great accommodation: we visited after our day in wilderness but decided to come back by night rather than sleep over at the park

I was looking forward to some great wild life photos and with a very slight chance of seeing a leopard. It was very tired looking bush, all water holes were very low or dry. We saw a few water birds, a viper, monitor, a kingfisher, 2 close up eagles some wart hogs, a mongoose, a bear and some good shots of spotted deers. Oh we also came across two leopard footprints on sandy track. I have probably been spoiled with excellent wild life experiences in South America and stunning experiences in Africa but even so I was disappointed. Our driver and spotter were willing workers but lacked the skills for searching and approaching wildlife. Driving too quick through tree areas and no quick response possible to driver when one of us spotted an animal/bird. My recommendation is that it is worth going there on the chance you could be lucky but are prepared to accept that you may see very little.
